Name: The Wolf of Wall Street
Review:
One of my favorite movies of all time. Admittedly a lot of it is with the circumstances of my first viewing. 

I watched this for the first time in theaters in December 2013, just rewatched it again. My first viewing was when I just started college (and was a sucker for anything raunchy). This hit me a certain way because it was not only raunchy but also meticulously crafted. A super long runtime, but always engrossing. Still canâ€™t believe a lot of the scenes actually happened in real life. Leo deserved the Oscar for this.

Name: Forrest Gump
Review: This film always holds a special place in my heart. A great retelling of US history through a fascinating character. Groundbreaking visual effects for its time. Probably the first time I remember where visual effects were utilized smartly, rather than just for actiony explosions.

Name: Last Night in Soho
Review:
Iâ€™m a fan of all of Edgar Wrightâ€™s prior films - they have smart humor and meticulous editing. So I was very interested to see his next film in a very different genre. I love it when artists venture against type - the best example is writer Craig Mazin who started with movies like the Hangover sequels and then randomly gave us Chernobyl. Another cool example is Todd Philips who went from directing the Hangover movies to Joker (funny how both of these examples include the Hangover)

I was fully engrossed through the runtime of Last Night in Soho, due to 2 major things:
1) Unique visuals. The shots between Thomasin McKenzie and Anya Taylor-Joyâ€™s characters were so meticulously edited. Iâ€™m glad Edgar Wright brought this signature into a different type of film. In addition, the pros and cons of the 1960s were visually captured vividly.Â 
2) Ellie (portrayed by Thomasin McKenzie) is a solid lead character. She comes with a rural innocence, a slightly haunting past, a fascination by the 1960s, and a dream for a future in fashion. We want her to be happy, but reality kicks in as she realizes that demeaning and immoral people exist and may push her away from her happy future.

As for cons, in hindsight certain plot points and choices had inconsistencies. They didnâ€™t make me hate the film in the end, but I wish more thought was put into connecting things together.Â 

Still, I was on board for the ride. I also always have a soft spot for films that donâ€™t fit into a singular genre. This is not a cookie cutter film by any means. Even though I didnâ€™t agree with every choice, I could tell that thought was put into each frame and I have to commend that.

Name: Goodbye
Review:
Heartwarming, with a couple humorous scenes. A nice explanation of what makes up the funeral process in Hindu culture. Iâ€™m a fan of anything Amitabh Bachchan does - I love his range of film involvement.Â 

The film had some scenes that dragged too long though. A perfect version of this film would be 45 minutes shorter.

Name: Colossal
Review:
I always look forward to films with a unique premise. And I typically rate those films higher than normal because uniqueness typically adds to how much I appreciate a film. Unfortunately, I canâ€™t do that for Colossal.Â 

I love the premise of this movie. An imperfect individual is randomly in control of a giant creature in Seoul. That has so much comedy potential. And I saw that comedy potential in every scene that Anne Hathaway + company acted fun and silly together.Â 

But, this film decided to try so much more and it just ended up messy. A subplot where Anne Hathawayâ€™s character is kicked out and her ex is trying to win her back. Jason Sudeikis having a complete 180 degree in character choices for no reason. And a final resolution that was so ludicrous that I couldnâ€™t help but facepalm. All this took away from the uniqueness that I wanted to appreciate so much.

Name: Rocky II
Review:
A sequel that I actually like more than the original!

I liked the original and definitely appreciate its impact on film, but I felt that some scenes werenâ€™t as cleanly edited together as I wanted.Â 

Rocky II is stitched together perfectly in my opinion. From the start, I could tell this sequel was actually justified. Rocky Balboa and Apollo Creed enter Rocky II in a way that makes sense. Rocky is suddenly famous and doesnâ€™t know how to navigate the new fame. Apollo didnâ€™t expect a tough fight and feels like he lost even though he technically won. Iâ€™m thankful we got a chance to view the aftermath of the fight from the prior film - itâ€™s a story I actually cared about viewing.Â 

Rockyâ€™s journey back into the ring was fascinating to me. At first itâ€™s great - he buys expensive things without much thought. But then the sponsorships and endorsements just donâ€™t sit well with him. It doesnâ€™t feel genuine to him, and we agree as a viewer of the film. Even if he could cruise for the rest of his life with the financial fame from the original fight, he is first and foremost a boxer. He tries going back into boxing, but his wifeâ€™s initial disapproval hinders him from giving it his all. He then drops everything to care for his wife during a pregnancy complication. Once she is better and approves of the return to boxing, he is able to give it his all.Â 

The final fight was a thrilling show. I was so invested that It felt like I was watching a real fight. It all went naturally how youâ€™d expect based on how you know the characters. Rocky is still the underdog and Apollo will not play easy this time around. Ultimately, the one with the better mental game won.Â 

Finally, this made me really appreciate Sylvester Stallone. Today heâ€™s sorta known as just a macho guy making typical macho films. Two films in, the Rocky franchise has more depth than I expected. And in Rocky II, he even directed it (along with writing it and acting as the main character). I look forward to check out the rest of his work, I bet there are more hidden gems out there.

Name: Women Talking
Review:
This reminded me a lot like Aaron Sorkinâ€™s screenplay work. Snappy dialogue elevated this film to a thrilling level. Definitely worthy of the Oscar for adapted screenplay.Â 

If a similar topic of conversation occurred today, weâ€™d likely see similar points brought up. This made it very investing to see how the film would ultimately conclude.

Name: Last Seen Alive
Review: A time pass thriller. Didnâ€™t really do anything wrong or bad per se, it was just strongly normal. There are many other better thrillers out there.

Name: The Hangover Part III
Review:
This trilogy shouldâ€™ve just been a one and done movie. Clearly part 2 and part 3 only exist to make money.Â 

I slightly prefer part 3 over part 2, mainly because I appreciated that they tried a different genre with the same characters. I would like to see more franchises that can take risks with varied genres in the same franchise. Unfortunately, not much was done with the risk for part 3.Â Most jokes didnâ€™t land, and I really couldnâ€™t stand Ken Jeongâ€™s character. Frankly, I was just waiting for the movie to end.

Name: Chernobyl
Review:
An absolutely thrilling ride.Â 

There are many disaster films out there. What set this mini-series apart was what happens when a disaster takes place in a socialist regime like the Soviet Union.

A normal disaster film generally displays to us from the start why a disaster happened, and every character is focused on curbing the effects of the disaster. In Chernobyl, most of the first half was leaders downplaying the disaster, and the political backlash against people trying to curb the effects. It emphasizes the importance of our political leaders doing their job if, god-forbid, a disaster were to occur.Â The heroic work we see is further elevated, knowing that if they did survive they could end up getting punished by political leaders.

Name: Daddy Day Care
Review: Revisited a childhood classic of mine, and it still holds up. My second favorite childhood memory of Eddie Murphy (after Shrek).

Name: The Menu
Review:
What a unique premise!

Yes, there are social commentary connections you can make with this film. I frankly just liked this on the surface level of an unpredictable plot. I had no idea what direction the film was going, and I was all for it.Â 

I never thought it would be possible for Ralph Fiennes to play a character scarier than Voldemort. Who wouldâ€™ve expected that not only would that occur, but it would be as a chefâ€¦

This film is further elevated with smart humorous dialogue and stellar performances across the board.Â 

I still canâ€™t get over how unique of a film this is. There is no single genre that can describe this film, and I doubt weâ€™ll ever see a film similar to this again.

Name: Moonfall
Review:
Is this a groundbreaking piece of art? No. Do I care? Also no!

The Room is typically cited as the best â€œso bad, itâ€™s goodâ€ film. I get the charm of The Room, but I never really felt a strong need to revisit it for fun.Â 

I 100% would host an annual movie night to watch Moonfall. The ridiculousness levels perfectly escalate through the runtime. Without spoiling anything, the concept of the moon crashing towards Earth is frankly one of the more normal parts of this film.Â 

To anyone giving this film a bad review: did you really expect perfection or though-provoking art going into this? If so, you watched this film very wrong.

Name: Primer
Review:
Mainstreams films that involve time travel usually gloss over the science and logic behind the time travel to focus on the thrilling sequences from the plot. Primer flips that focus.Â 

Wow. What a big-brain film. Respect to anyone that can watch this film and actually understand it. I understood maybe 10% of this film, and subsequently needed hours of YouTube videos explaining what I just watched. I definitely need to watch this again at some point to solve this puzzle.Â 

Huge kudos to the filmmakers that created something so thoughtful on a puny budget. It makes me want to say that films with a sloppy screenplay really have no excuse ğŸ˜‚

Iâ€™m docking one star on this, mainly because Iâ€™m personally not the biggest fan of super big brain films. Doesnâ€™t detract from the respect I have for the film though.

Name: Pathaan
Review:
Aggressively fine is how Iâ€™d describe this.Â 

I get the hype and anticipation around this - Shah Rukh Khanâ€™s first film in five years. He has strong charisma and charms audiences. I myself am a huge fan too, Iâ€™ve grown up watching his movies. However, his later movies havenâ€™t really had the same charm and legacy as his earlier movies. I feel the same way about Pathaan- I doubt this will really be a â€œtimeless classicâ€. I wish I could see Shah Rukh Khan do more unique roles again like Chak De India or Dear Zindagi.Â 

A lot of things just felt slightly off here. I think I would pinpoint this to inconsistent tones. The dialogue had some serious lines and then some cheesy lines - it wouldâ€™ve been nice to just commit one way or the other. The chemistry between Shah Rukh Khan and Deepika Padukoneâ€™s characters felt more forced than fun.Â 

All the actors look great as action stars, but I couldnâ€™t get into the action fully due to the subpar visual effects. I understand that Indian films have an exponentially lower budget than US blockbusters so by no means do I expect Mission Impossible quality. But, a lot of the action scenes unfortunately looked like blatant green screen so I couldnâ€™t feel the tension that the film wanted me to. I donâ€™t remember feeling this sane way about the visual effects for other films in this YRF Spy Universe like Ek Tha Tiger or War.Â 

This film trying showing off a lot of spectacle but it didnâ€™t stick the landing for me. I think that there needs to be more focus on original screenplay than trying to imitate Hollywood spectacle. RRR got a huge worldwide following because, despite visual effects not being completely on par with Hollywood, it embraced and built upon Indian culture and storytelling and felt fresh to audiences.Â 

Two positives I will say about Pathaan:
1) I bought John Abrahamâ€™s villainous motive. While he was doing terrorist actions, I understood why he felt he was doing the right thing.Â 
2) The continuation of this YRF Spy Universe is pretty cool. I would totally see an â€œAvengersâ€ film in this universe that pulls Shah Rukh Khan, Salman Khan, and Hrithik Roshan into the same movie.

Name: Rocky III
Review:
Even though I think the first and second films are better, Iâ€™m content that this third film is actually justified. This doesnâ€™t seem like an overdone franchise so far, and I hope to feel the same way as I watch the rest.Â 

Like the last one, this film is a natural next story following Rocky II. It made sense for Rocky to hit an athletic peak at the end Rocky II, and then stagnate and slowly drop. A new character as a foil to Rocky was perfect to tell this story.Â 

I also appreciated the friendship between Rocky and Apollo. They were rivals in the past, and then the mutual respect blossomed into a friendship.Â 

Iâ€™m strongly mixed on the tonal shift of this film. While the previous films felt real, this one added parts that felt like a caricature. Hulk Hoganâ€™s fight and Clubber Langâ€™s persona were very fun (and it was great to learn this is where Mr. Tâ€™s â€œI pity the fool!â€ originated), but the placement into a Rocky franchise just felt odd.Â 

I also really didnâ€™t buy the relevation that Mickey gave to Rocky after the statue unveiling scene. I feel like Rocky wouldâ€™ve been smart enough to figure that out himself. Unfortunately, a lot of the motivation in the film depends on buying into this.

Name: Varudu Kaavalenu
Review:
This started as a typical cute romcom, and went so downhill in the second half.Â 

The first half introduced the girl with a unique personality as the owner of a small business and has a demeaning presence. We expect to soon hear background on why sheâ€™s like that. Instead, the second half decides to avoid that question, and turn into a typical Telugu movie with many silly conveniences.Â 

A huge nitpick I had was that the boy came from Dubai, but characters kept saying he came from Paris.

Name: Beast
Review:
A creature feature filmed very well!

I donâ€™t really get why this got mediocre reviews - I was thoroughly invested through the whole filmâ€™s thrills.Â 

The natural visuals of the African wilderness are absolutely beautiful. I also loved the night shots - they didnâ€™t seem super dark or a cheap ploy to get around an easier visual effects process.Â 

There are many one shots, and I have no idea how they filmed those shots. The one shots definitely move it up above an average thriller level.Â 

I totally believed Idris Elbaâ€™s role in this film. He plays a doctor and a father trying to reconnect with his daughters, while also being a character thatâ€™s somewhat competent with weapons and hurting lions. Thatâ€™s a lot of buy-in to expect from the audience, but I bought it since heâ€™s a great actor.Â 

Docking one star because one of the characters has many stupid decisions out of the blue, seemingly just to increase the tension. They couldâ€™ve put some effort in a couple moments to naturally build the tension. Even something as little as a lion cracking a car window wouldâ€™ve prevent the need for stupid decisions.

Name: Kimi
Review:
An engrossing contained thriller!

Most of the film focuses on Zoe Kravitzâ€™s character, and she had an excellent performance here. I bought everything about her character background and her decisions.Â 

A slight tangent, but this showcases a great reason why I appreciate the art of film. Many throwaway films can have a throwaway supervillain flying through skyscrapers and killing many people, but somehow there is just no tension or fear. On the other hand, some of Kimiâ€™s scariest moments is just an agoraphobe walking outside. You donâ€™t need millions of CGI dollars to invest your audience - you just need to flesh out your characters and have a purpose behind Dutch angles.Â 

If youâ€™re a Home Alone fan like me - thereâ€™s a reference here thatâ€™s perfection.Â 

Dropping a half star because the very end went a normal thriller route, and I wouldâ€™ve expected something more unique given how the rest of the film was. It didnâ€™t tank the film for me though.

Name: M3GAN
Review:
Solid B-movie thriller!

Many critic reviews seem to focus on saying something like â€œthis is great for a film released in Januaryâ€. I donâ€™t like doing that - the legacy of a film shouldnâ€™t rely on its release date, but on the film itself.Â 

Iâ€™m astonished by how low this budget is given how realistic M3gan looked. I didnâ€™t observe any bad CGI or obvious puppeteering.Â 

My favorite parts were the moments of focusing on the social dangers of AI. The idea of a childâ€™s development corrupted by an AI powered toy is scarier to me than a murdering toy. I really wish the AI social commentary was explored more, instead of the horror kills.

This film clearly got all the hype from social media, like TikToks for the M3gan dance. Honestlyâ€¦ pretty smart marketing.

Name: Marcel the Shell with Shoes On
Review:
Another example of the fact that quality original content still exists!

The premise of this alone still astounds me - major credit to the filmmakers on the concept alone. And not only is it such a unique concept; itâ€™s family-friendly. Iâ€™ve grown up watching films through childhood and thatâ€™s really what got me into a love for film. As an adult, a part of me is sad that some of the greatest/artistic films are too inappropriate to be accessible to children. Thankfully, Marcel the Shell with Shoes On can have shared appreciation for all ages.Â 

I was captivated solely on Marcelâ€™s innocent outlook to new experiences. Adorable and thought-provoking.Â 

Iâ€™m docking one star simply because it didnâ€™t personally connect with me all that way. This is really less a fault on the film and more on movie - I totally understand people that would love this movie.

Name: Rocky IV
Review:
Another justified film in the franchise!

Iâ€™m content that four films in, we still have actual reason to follow the characters and buy into their arcs. Todayâ€™s franchises really need to take notes from the Rocky franchise.Â 

I appreciated Apollo Creedâ€™s death as the center of this film. Apolloâ€™s cockiness was consistent with his personality of the previous films, so it made sense that he wanted to stay in the ring with Ivan Drogo until his eventual demise. This death also gives believable motivation for Rocky to fight Ivan. Finally, a death in the ring further shows just how dangerous boxing is, which adds a lot of tension for the final fight.Â 

While reading upon the production background, I learned that the boxing scenes were legitimately filmed. In one instance, Sylvester Stallone got heart swelling and needed to be urgently transported to the hospital. In another instance, Carl Weathers almost quit the film because of a fight scene with Dolph Lundgren going way too overboard. Huge respect for shooting practical shots.Â 

Couple things didnâ€™t work for me here:
- The robot â€œcharacterâ€ was super weird and didnâ€™t fit into the overall tone.Â 
- Ivanâ€™s backstory seemed cartoonish. He was displayed as a Russian manufactured object with no personality. This came off to me more as comical than scary.Â 
- The middle has multiple back-to-back montages. While all filmed well, it got overboard.Â 
- While the final fight scenes were shot practically, somehow I didnâ€™t feel that way compared to the final fight of Rocky II. I think itâ€™s because this final fight had many quick edits, so we didnâ€™t stay sustained enough in singular shots to feel realistic.Â 
- The US vs. Russia sentiment got very heavy handed, especially with Rockyâ€™s speech at the end. I get that this film came out during Soviet times, but that speech is not believable to be made by Rocky. He fought to avenge Apollo, not for his country.Â 

Iâ€™ve heard that all these cons were addressed in the directors cut of the film. I would love to check that out someday.

Name: Missing
Review:
Searching was one of my favorite films in the year it came out. Still canâ€™t forget that theater experience. The â€œscreenlifeâ€ aspect wasnâ€™t just a gimmick, but a smartly edited and investing storytelling medium through the whole runtime.Â 

Missing was made by the same creators, so thereâ€™s no surprise that itâ€™s also amazing!

I was afraid of this falling into a sequel trope, where it just copies a lot from the original and doesnâ€™t have its own flavor. In many ways, it shares similar aspects to the original. But, the thrill was so engrossing that I truly didnâ€™t care - why deviate from a formula that works so well?

I think what made this feel fresh enough for me was the switch in relationship. In Searching, the daughter is missing and the father is searching. This explored the fatherâ€™s attempts to try being a protective father without pushing boundaries. On the other hand in Missing, the daughter is searching and the mother is missing. This explored the daughterâ€™s yearn for independence, and then appreciating her motherâ€™s love once she is missing. While very similar plot points, we could explore what would happen if the roles were reversed.Â 

Storm Reid was excellent in this. The whole film rests basically on her performance. Iâ€™m sure thereâ€™s an extra level of skill needed to act through webcam cameras all the time, and she sold everything. In addition, her character makes smart decisions at every turn - probably smarter than the everyday audience member. That helps with rooting for her character through the runtime.Â 

Another thing that makes this film stand out is the screenplay - very strongly written mystery thriller. It could still exist as an engrossing film even without the screenlife schtick. Just when you think you witnessed every twist, thereâ€™s more coming.Â 

I do slightly prefer Searching over Missing. This is likely a huge bias since I saw Searching first, so Iâ€™m curious to hear from others that saw Missing first. But, another reason was that I could actually believe Searching could occur in real life. Missing hadÂ a lot of conveniences to buy into. None of the conveniences detracted me from the thrill, but it was enough to make me feel it wasnâ€™t perfectly realistic.

Name: The Lost City
Review:
An enjoyable brainless comedy.Â 

I just went through a long work week and finished the first semester of my masters. After all that, I wanted to watch a movie but not a type that required my full attention to detail. The Lost City was perfect for my mood at this time.Â 

Yes, you could easily nitpick this movie and observe all the inconsistencies. Yes, you could say that this is ridiculously silly. Yes, there are other rom-coms that are more robustly edited together. Just donâ€™t think that too much and youâ€™ll have a fun ride.Â 

What elevated this movie beyond the forgettable realm was the characters - Iâ€™d happily watch another film with Sandra Bullock, Channing Tatum, Daniel Radcliffe, and Brad Pitt playing these characters again.Â 

While this isnâ€™t amazing or iconic, Iâ€™m glad this movie was successful and I hope we can continue to get more movies like this.

Name: The Sound of Music
Review:
This is an absolute joy from start to finish and still holds up so well.Â 

I definitely listened to the songs before and enjoy them. But, going into it I was afraid this would be like many other older movies - much slower pace compared to todayâ€™s films and may feel like a chore to sit through. Totally did not experience that :)

It may have a super long run time, but I genuinely did not want it to end! I was closely engrossed into every scene with a giant smile on my face. Mariaâ€™s love of life is infectious. Each of the kids have a joyful innocence.Â 

Each musical number fit so well with the plot of the film. The cinematography of the scenes were an absolute joy.Â 

We need more family-friendly movies like this made today. Most comedies today are either safe animated childrenâ€™s films or stoner comedies. Nothing in between. Iâ€™m confident if another film like The Sound of Music was made today, it would be very very successful. Hollywood, I hope you read this review and act upon it.

Name: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
Review:
A sorta normal movie elevated by David Fincherâ€™s direction.Â 

As of this review, I watched every David Fincher movie except The Game and Mank. For now, Iâ€™d rank The Curious Case of Benjamin Button at the lowest of his films. Not necessarily a jab at this film, more that Fincher makes great films ğŸ™‚

Admittedly, I think I wouldâ€™ve appreciated this film much more if I watched it at the time it was released. I think I wouldâ€™ve appreciated the unique schtick of a backwards aging human, and really appreciated the visual effects it took to create this.Â 

All these years later, Benjamin Button has become joked about so much that I think it lessened the uniqueness of the concept for me. It felt like I just watched Brad Pittâ€™s character experience life. Definitely a well directed life by David Fincher, but there wasnâ€™t really much more than that.Â 

Visual effects are definitely strong - I didnâ€™t pinpoint any blatant CGI. But, de-aging has become a common technology now so itâ€™s hard for me to praise the visual effects that many other films are now doing too.Â 

That being said, I donâ€™t think I can sleep well at night if I gave this a negative review. All the acting is great, the world is well realized, Fincherâ€™s direction is solid, and clearly every cast and crew member brought their A-game. Itâ€™s worth a one-time watch, but I donâ€™t see myself revisiting this again.

Name: Balagam
Review:
A realistically shot film about a death that occurs in a village in Telengana. Would like to see mainstream films more like this than like throwaway masala movies.Â 

I felt mixed around the family drama choices made. On one side, some of them were realistic. On the other hand, they also felt like unnecessary distractions from the main focus.

Name: Rocky V
Review:
A fine addition to the franchise. Iâ€™m neither angry with its existence nor was upset with missed opportunities.Â 

This had a good number of positive aspects, despite how much fans (and Stallone himself) try to forget this film. I like that this film went the direction of Rocky becoming a mentor for Tommy Gunn, and then actually fights him in the end. I like that this went small scale rather than trying to one-up an international fight from Rocky IV. I like that Rockyâ€™s love of boxing was distracting him from being a proper from his son, and then seeing the consequences of this.Â 

A couple scenes got really cheesy, which makes me agree that this is the worst so far in the franchise. Not bad though. Other franchises have had much worse (like Fallen Kingdom and Dominion for Jurassic Park, or Alien Resurrection for Alien)

Name: Dune
Review:
Proof that a film can have both depth and a strong theater experience!

My biggest regret is that I didnâ€™t watch this film in theaters. I will definitely watch Part 2 in IMAX later this year.Â 

The visual effects are absolutely breathtaking. I was completely immersed in this world. Literally every shot can be a solid movie poster on a wall. Â There really is no other film world like this one, as far as I know.Â 

My biggest concern going into this movie was that it would be so deep into lore that only fans of the book series can follow along. Thankfully, it was not complicated. It had a solid amount of story and smartly educated the viewer about the rules of this world, without feeling too exposition heavy.Â 

It seems like lots of criticisms center around the fact that this film is only a first half of the story. I really donâ€™t get why that should be a criticism. Itâ€™s not like the studio assembly line franchises that make certain films just to set up the next one in the franchise (e.g. the Julia Louis-Dreyfuss scenes in Black Panther: Wakanda Forever). This film just told a story and put a bookmark in the middle, in my opinion.Â 

Denis Villeneuve, you are one of the best working directors today. Your films have both spectacle and depth. I will always look forward to anything you do!

Name: Are You There God? It's Me, Margaret.
Review:
A solid coming-of-age story.Â 

This was one of the few movies where I went into it knowing absolutely nothing (other than itâ€™s based on a book).Â 

Personally I donâ€™t believe in the idea that I obviously wonâ€™t like a movie if Iâ€™m not the target audience. Yes, certain groups of people may love certain genres more than others. But, if a film is made well enough, it can connect with any viewer. For example, Iâ€™m nothing like the characters in Mean Girls but I still enjoy watching that and laugh at all the jokes.Â 

This film is about a sixth grade girl that navigates problems like navigating what religion she is, boys noticing her, wanting big boobs, and expecting her first period. I obviously donâ€™t relate to any of that, but I was engrossed with witnessing how Margaret navigates these issues.Â 

It was also relieving to see a film set in the 1980s. Away from social media or smartphones - we see the the kids have fun with things like running through sprinklers rather than Snapchat filters.Â 

Docking one star only because there wasnâ€™t really anything groundbreaking here. Iâ€™m sure it will connect well to some people that see it at a certain age. But there really isnâ€™t much more for me to rave about it (or even watch it again).

Name: Galaxy Quest
Review:
This is likely the best parody movie to ever exist. Go watch it if you havenâ€™t already!Â 

Most parody movies donâ€™t really go into it with a goal of trying to be â€œgoodâ€. They seem to lean heavily into the â€œso bad itâ€™s goodâ€ realm (e.g. Sharknado) and run by with just references to what they are poking fun at. And especially if you havenâ€™t seen (or even like) the source material (e.g. Spaceballs*), you wonâ€™t take much away from the parody movie.

The best praise I can give to Galaxy Quest is that it is able to exist on its own. A lot of this film is similar to the Star Trek world. I personally have a pretty basic knowledge of Star Trek, but I was still very engrossed in Galaxy Quest. Iâ€™m sure Star Trek knowledge would elevate this film further, but itâ€™s definitely not necessary to enjoy the film.Â 

Despite the film definitely being a comedy, there is a perfect amount of actual tension. I found myself actually at the edge of my seat during the third act - I canâ€™t even say that about many actual action films made today.Â 

The concept of this film is very fresh. This couldâ€™ve gone a typical parody route and have the characters actually be spaceship managers. Instead, they were washed up actors of spaceship managers in an actual spaceship. This brings a lot of comedy that just writes itself, but also brings tension because of how incompetent they actually are for the tasks at hand. I expected the concept to get tired by the halfway point, but it really didnâ€™t.Â 

Itâ€™s also interesting to view this many years later. This film very well predicted the craziness of todayâ€™s fandom, both in positive and negative aspects.Â Similarly, Itâ€™s so funny to me that Sigourney Weaver and Alan Rickman were cast in this film. Sigourney Weaver was the iconic Ellen Ripley in the Alien films, and Alan Rickman would later be Snape in the Harry Potter films. I bet they have experienced similar levels of weird fandom as they played actual iconic characters before.Â 

There are two side actors in this film that I didnâ€™t know were in it beforehand. Not gonna spoil it if you donâ€™t know, but once I saw them I randomly got so happy and so much more excited to experience the rest of this film.Â 

This was not a cookie-cutter, assembly line parody film generated from the movie executives. There was a lot of thought actually put into this. People wanting smart comedy will get that. People wanting thrills will get that too.Â 

*Donâ€™t interpret this as me saying Spaceballs is bad. I definitely enjoyed that movie. Iâ€™m merely making the point that appreciating Spaceballs depends on knowing Star Wars.

Name: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery
Review:
Great hero and villain caricatures in an ok film.Â 

My improv class recently had a final show, and some of my classmates played Dating Game. In this game, someone is on a Dating Game show interviewing three contestants. Each contestant plays a character suggested by the audience. One of the contestants was â€œDr. Evilâ€ - the audience laughed at all the clues, and the guesser guessed correctly. I felt embarrassed that I didnâ€™t understand any of these reference (in fact, didnâ€™t even know this was a part of the Austin Powers universe), so I knew I had to catch up on knowledge by watching this film.Â 

I understand why this film series has a cult following. Mike Myers is super talented. Austin Powers and Dr. Evil are hilarious characters. Many of the innuendos and references to old James Bond films are on point. In a way, Iâ€™m glad this franchise exists because it forced James Bond films to movie to the serious route than continue silly tones.Â 

This was a fun one-time watch. I see myself rewatching some scenes on YouTube, but donâ€™t care enough to watch the film itself again. Iâ€™m interested enough to see the other two films, but admittedly not the most excited.

Name: Somebody I Used to Know
Review:
Nothing wrong with this film per se. The main thing is I ended the film wishing I spent my time elsewhere. I felt like everything this film offered exists in better ways in other rom-coms (and even soap operas).Â 

Was cool to see Alison Brie and Danny Pudi reunite after Community though.

Name: Side Effects
Review:
A good slow-burn with solid performances from Rooney Mara and Jude Law.Â 

I havenâ€™t seen most of Steven Soderberghâ€™s filmography, but I am fascinated by his variety. He made the Oceanâ€™s trilogy which are solid heist films, as well as Contagion which scathingly accurately predicted how humans react to COVID. So I am always ready to experience any of his films.Â 

This film is definitely thrilling - I was invested and looking forward to explore where the plot was going. I overall was on board with all the plot choices made here.Â 

But in hindsight, I donâ€™t really feel like anything groundbreaking or hugely unique occurred here. And I donâ€™t feel super enthusiastic to advertise that people have to watch this film.Â 

This film is oddly similar to Gone Girl, and Iâ€™d recommend you watch that film over this one.

Name: Chip 'n Dale: Rescue Rangers
Review:
Iâ€™m sad to give this a negative review because it shows that I am definitely not a kid anymore. The child version of myself wouldâ€™ve LOVED this movie.Â 

I do give this movie credit for having hilarious use of the IP this straight-to-Disney+ movie somehow had. It references a lot more than just Disney-owned properties, and I donâ€™t know how it got away with it.Â 

Other than that though, itâ€™s really just a typical harmless kids movie. Follows all the expected tropes.

Name: The Kerala Story
Review:
Note: This film has come across heavy controversy in India, for potentially factual inaccuracies and phobic propaganda. I really donâ€™t want to add to controversy, so Iâ€™m not going to comment directly on the touchy topics or my opinions on them. Iâ€™ll only discuss the filmmaking here.
In addition, unrelated to this specific film: Iâ€™ve seen many political films either praised or criticized, purely based on the political affiliation of the critic. I wish critics did a better job of reviewing the filmmaking with a neutral viewpoint, and then separating their political thoughts in another segment.Â 

Before watching this film, I was curious to hear why someone could potentially be convinced into a dangerous ideology. What this film does a really good job of is showing how the convincing is so effective. Target people that seem to not have strong personal opinions. Personally dig into tragedies that occurred in their past, and share how your ideology wouldâ€™ve prevented that tragedy. Have many individuals involved in varying degrees of â€œgood cop, bad copâ€. And on top of that, have no concrete proof that all this happened so you can â€œlegallyâ€ get away with it. This is what made the film particularly gut-wrenching for me: this is very real and can easily happen to anyone we know.Â 

This is a really difficult and graphic watch, but I think itâ€™s not over-the-top. Itâ€™s done to enough of a degree to show just how tragic the circumstances are.Â 

The film makes a narrative choice to concurrently follow three timelines:
1) Shalini getting interviewed by the authorities
2) Shaliniâ€™s background that led to her conversion (which is the content of her interview)
3) Shaliniâ€™s life post-conversion (which then eventually also becomes the content of her interview)
Surprisingly, all this is actually easy to follow and not confusing. But, I couldnâ€™t help but wish this was done chronologically instead. It wouldâ€™ve added much more tension on wondering if she would make it out alive. I get the goal of this film was to bring awareness of the topic (as opposed to being a fictional thriller), but I still view this as a better film structure.

Name: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania
Review: ChatGPT input: write the next MCU film ChatGPT output: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania I came out of this film even more frustrated with the state of the MCU. I wish they would move efforts to focusing on quality instead of quantity, this is really getting out of hand. Everything just felt like corporate creations with no heart or joy.Â  This is best contrasted with Dune. Dune is a world that hasnâ€™t been majorly visualized before by mainstream audiences in the 21st century. But, Villeneuveâ€™s film truly immersed you into the world. This was done not just by the amazing visual effects, but by the character development and story and scope all coming together perfectly. The rules of the world are also fascinating: sand worms, shields, spice, and so much more. Despite how many films exist, the world of Dune feels so fresh and unique amongst any other film world. I came out of Dune eagerly awaiting to hear more stories around this world.Â  Similarly, the Quantum Realm was never majorly visualized up until this film. Weâ€™ve seen scenes here and there in prior MCU films, but never actually living in it until this film. Our imagination should run wild what to expect here. But, weâ€™re not given the time to immerse into this world. And the world really isnâ€™t that fascinating - we see human-like appearances in generally normal clothing and human-like bars. Anything that could be potentially perceived with a â€œwowâ€ remark ends up just being setup for a stupid one-off joke.Â  I was equally underwhelmed with the multiverse as shown in Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness. You have access to literally multiple universes, and pizza balls is the most creative thing we witness here?? Then thereâ€™s the overall premise. It all depends on two huge conveniences.Â  1) Ant-Manâ€™s daughter is super into science and technology, and she just tinkered around to find a way to get into the Quantum Realm. Weâ€™ve seen many other teenage geniuses in the MCU. I bought Peter Parker since heâ€™s Spider-Man and got superpowers. I bought Shuri because she is in Wakanda, which is basically a different world from the rest of Earth. I started to lose believability with Ironheart in Black Panther: Wakanda Forever because that had almost no backstory and it was just clearly setup for the next Disney+ show. Now, we got even less setup in this film. And on top of that, she had no backstory with fighting but we have to believe that she can fight huge armies and win.Â  2) Janet had a huge scarring history in the Quantum Realm with Kang spanning multiple years, but told no one about it until Ant-Manâ€™s daughter opens up to the Quantum Realm.Â  Many people praised Kang in this film. I agree that Jonathan Majors is good, but I worry about the buildup to him becoming the next Thanos. There are many Kang versions - will we see a different version (and therefore completely different character arcs) in each film? Is it worth investing in each Kang version? The prior Ant-Man films werenâ€™t necessarily my favorites, but at least they had great jokes. Here, the writing seemed to be exponentially worse with comedy. It felt like there were no jokes for some time, then they realized they have to add a joke so they inappropriately shoehorned a joke in.Â  In addition, there was no connection between the prior Ant-Man films and this one. Michael PeÃ±a and crew are not here, and they had natural comic relief in the past films. While I disagreed with the weird comedy nature in the Quantum Realm, Michael PeÃ±a and crew wouldâ€™ve been a hilarious juxtaposition with this vibe. Instead, those people are forgotten and the focus was on the new character of Ant-Manâ€™s daughter.Â  The Wasp and Michael Douglas were also not done justice here. They were supposed to be very smart and important characters in the past, but here they were basically forgotten.Â  Before watching this film, I didnâ€™t realize that MODOK is a huge Marvel villain. MODOK was definitely not done well here - not that menacing, looked terrible, immediately forgotten. MODOK shouldâ€™ve been saved for a better story.Â  I almost was gonna turn around my thoughts at the very end when I saw it was potentially ending with a unique story for the next film to solve. But then, plot armor kicked in and then that issue was solved incredibly easily and the film ended in a completely normal way.Â  I was generally ok with the Phase 4 MCU films, and strongly mixed on the MCU tv series. If the rest of the MCU will be this quality, Iâ€™m going to quit the ride.Â  What a waste of $200 million.

Name: Werewolf by Night
Review:
Dear MCU - please make more content like this!Â 

What a breath of fresh air amongst all the MCU cookie cutter content.Â 

Personally, the type of franchise I want is one where each project has different genres. The closest weâ€™ve really gotten is Alien (sci-fi horror) and Aliens (sci-fi thriller), and then the rest of the entries sorta derailed. Another version is the Cloverfield franchise (until The Cloverfield Paradox) derailed it. Other than that, every major franchise has the same type of content within it.Â 

Werewolf by Night is very different from the rest of the MCU. Apart from the credits, you could tell me this wasnâ€™t the MCU and I wouldâ€™ve believed you. I mean this totally as a compliment. Any non-superhero fan would appreciate this.Â 

Every character in this film is brand new, but I genuinely cared about all of them. I didnâ€™t even feel this way about other MCU properties that had multiple films or episodes of time to buy me over.Â 

The acting is on point. People being scared didnâ€™t seem like theatrical overacting, but that they were acting as anyone naturally would when the see a monster!Â 
In addition, this film has more gore than other MCU content. I mean this in a good way - things actually seemed scary enough to describe it as a true horror movie.Â 

I really like that this was filmed as a black-and-white, old theater cinematography. Ultimately I donâ€™t know if there was a larger thematic reason for the choice, but I still like the choice.Â 

My main criticism is I wish this was an actual movie length with a theater release. They struck gold with the characters, actors, and tone here. They shouldâ€™ve leaned into this more to retain MCU audiences that are losing interest. This couldâ€™ve been a monster hunt game filmed in real-time. Anyone wouldâ€™ve been thrilled by this. Itâ€™s a shame that the lower quality properties got hours worth of content in films and tv series, while this one didnâ€™t even get one hour. Â 

If the MCU makes more content like this, Iâ€™ll be sold back.

Name: Pitch Perfect
Review:
This is my guilty pleasure. No judgment please!

Sidebar- I almost marked this one as a rewatch because I thought I definitely saw this trilogy before. But I totally didnâ€™t - Iâ€™ve just seen random clips on YouTube. So once I started this film and realized I had no idea about basic plot elements (e.g. Anna Kendrickâ€™s character is a DJ), I then realized I never actually watched this franchise. That was a funny realization.Â 

I think what makes me rank this higher than normal is two things:
1) I have a soft spot for anything acapella.Â 
2) All the characters are just weird enough to work well together.Â 

Iâ€™m definitely gonna enjoy throwing this on the tv every so often when I want a reliable smile.Â 

Two things that prevent me from ranking this perfect:
1) I go back and forth on if the inappropriate humor actually gels well with this film. On one side, they are in college so of course it happens. And if this was just an acapella drama rather than mainly a comedy, I doubt it wouldâ€™ve been as popular. On the other hand, there are definitely moments where jokes go one too many.Â 
2) Some story elements couldâ€™ve been a little more fleshed out. For example, there is a character that has a case of puking. The movie makes you expect that eventually thereâ€™s an explanation for the puking (e.g. she pukes when sheâ€™s really stressed), but it never actually explains it.

Name: A Man Called Otto
Review: A unique feel-good film with a solid Tom Hanks performance! Tom Hanks has been a top actor since he was young. A lot of actors with a strong filmography tend to stop caring in their later years. Iâ€™m so happy that Tom Hanks still cares about his performance even in his later years. He could be an immature kid in Big, and now be a grumpy crank in A Man Called Otto and seem flawless in both.Â  Despite the main character being a grumpy crank, this film can be enjoyable by all ages. Anyone can understand why he is grumpy, but also anyone can wish he could lighten up. Heâ€™s not hateful at heart and clearly doesnâ€™t hate people for no reason - this is important to keep rooting for his betterment.Â  Mariana TreviÃ±oâ€™s performance also elevated this film for me. She acts exactly like what a caring neighbor would do in the situation.Â  Sure, this follows the plot points you expect. But these type of films are not meant to surprise you. Itâ€™s about the journey you take with them. You will smile and cry at all the right moments.Â  My main criticism is that certain conveniences took place near the end to tie things up into a perfect bow. I slightly wish that more effort went into meeting these story beats. It didnâ€™t take away from my emotions with the film though, so not major for me.

Name: Till
Review:
An absolute gut-wrenching film.Â 

My historical background was knowing Emmett Till was lynched, had an open casket funeral to show the disgusting nature of lynching, and this being an important step towards civil rights justice.Â 

Somehow it didnâ€™t hit me how young Emmett Till was until seeing this film. He was just a kid. Literally only 14 years old. No matter how you look at it, absolutely did not deserve this fate. And this happened in 1955 - not at all long ago. I know people today that were alive at that time. Iâ€™m thankful how far society progressed since that time, but still shocking that this happened relatively recently.Â 

Danielle Deadwyler as Mamie was absolutely amazing. Any mother or anyone close to their mother will connect to this performance. She is a hero for pushing for justice for Emmett despite every reason fighting against her. The film does a great job of showing the difficulties and how she fights through them.
Absolute robbery that Danielle Deadwyler got no major acting wins (or even nominations).Â 

The film focuses on all the right parts of this story. We see the state of Emmett Till post-murder, just like how everyone else saw the open-casket funeral. We see the gross tactics the opposing side does to win the trial. We see how all sides of the media react to the news. All this makes us feel like we were a fly on the wall in 1955 witnessing these events, and makes us angrier knowing the outcome doesnâ€™t go the proper way.Â 

A must watch for all.

Name: The Fabelmans
Review: Anyone will be able to connect to an extent with this film. Youâ€™ll probably love it more if you connect with it more.Â  Steven Spielberg is undoubtedly my favorite director - he basically created the modern day blockbuster, and has made the best of all genres. I admittedly havenâ€™t watched all of his filmography (nor do I love every film of his I watched), but I walk away from each film with strong respect to Spielberg.Â  A part of me feels bad to give any criticisms to this film because itâ€™s obviously a personal semi-autobiography of Spielberg. But, I must be honest with sharing the pros and cons of any film I watch.Â  My favorite moments are everything involving Sammyâ€™s work with filmmaking. We witness the exact moment when he falls in love with film from that theater experience. While any other person would probably talk on about their favorite scenes, Sammy actually acted upon it by trying to recreate how that was possible to capture on film. Anyone that is passionate about their hobby likely had a similar event in their life and will strongly relate to this introduction.Â  Itâ€™s admirable to also see that in his teenage years he also excelled in filmmaking. He definitely didnâ€™t know the basics of switching film reels and editing, but his passion gave the motivation to figure it out. He gave a passionate speech to an older actor to bring out the emotion into the final shot. He hosted viewing parties for all his family and friends, and they all loved his work. This is motivation goals that all of us should try to imitate.Â  My favorite scene was how his father, a super smart scientist, didnâ€™t know how Sammy captured the gunshots on film. When Sammy explained that he made holes in the film reel - I myself was mindblown too. This outside the box thinking is clearly what made Spielberg a strong director in his time.Â  Sidebar - the film nerd in me was very invested in how filmmaking worked back in the day. Now, you can just have smartphones to take videos and apps for editing. But back then, proper cameras and manual film reels were required. A much bigger hinderence to get into filmmaking, so extra kudos for all the older filmmakers for working through all that! The parts that didnâ€™t work for me as well were the family dynamics (again, I hate to critique this since it is based on his actual family). Iâ€™m not at all against including family dynamics - they can be a huge part in the motivations or detriments of people pursuing their passion. There were parts that felt very unique - Sammy learning about a family update through his past film reels. Sammy imagining himself filming a family fight. The struggles he faced after a move, and how film brought him back to happiness. Basically, anything that directly related to Sammy filmmaking worked well for me. All other family dynamic moments felt like a totally different movie.

Name: TÃR
Review:
Must be shocking that I didnâ€™t like the film thatâ€™s generally the best film of 2022.Â 

The main thing for me was that itâ€™s much longer than it needs to be - there are many scenes that could have been about half the time. So it felt like a chore to sit through it.Â 

Cate Blanchett was definitely good - personally I didnâ€™t feel she was interstellar like all the reviews though. I definitely wouldâ€™ve replaced Danielle Deadwyler from Till with her for the Academy Award nomination.Â 

When a main character is more on the immoral side, it can be difficult for a film to make you actually be invested into the character. One of the few that worked for me is Adam Sandler in Uncut Gems - he played a terrible human being, but I was so invested in the story that I still cared about how Adam Sandler would navigate this. On the other hand, I unfortunately didnâ€™t care enough about the story to be invested in Cate Blanchettâ€™s sorta immoral character.Â 

I watched a fair amount of reviews around this film - there admittedly is a lot of depth that I didnâ€™t pick up on during my watch. Once I learned this, I gained some more admiration for the film. However, itâ€™s not enough to make me want to sit through this long runtime to experience it again.

Name: Puss in Boots: The Last Wish
Review:
Surprisingly a very well written film with in-depth character arcs!

This film is a sequel to a spin-off of a franchise that undoubtedly got more films than it shouldâ€™ve. On paper, this shouldnâ€™t be a critically acclaimed film. But somehow, this actually works so well!

First off, Puss in Bootsâ€™ character arc is super investing. It makes sense both within this film and when you take the other filmsâ€™ backstory into account.Â 
His villain character (called the simple name â€œDeathâ€ but I promise actually has a lot more to him) is actually a great character to further explore Puss in Boots. To the point that I think Death is one of the scariest villains Iâ€™ve seen in film.Â 

Every side character also had a deep backstory and their own character arcs. Even Perrito, the comic relief side character! Thereâ€™s a specific scene between Puss in Boots and Perrito that almost made me tear up, knowing the relationship my brotherâ€™s dog has with our family.Â 

The first Shrek films had a freshness because they took fairy tale characters and took them in other fun directions. This film did the same with Goldilocks and the three bears. In a way this is actually a smart choice because these are known characters so the film doesnâ€™t need to spend as much time explaining who they are. So this film even paid proper homage to the first Shrek films!

And of course, the unique animation! It was a huge risk to deviate from the normal animation of the Shrek franchise. I expected this animation style to feel like a copy of Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse. But, this animation is not at all a copy - it took some inspiration, but also morphed it with the animation of the rest of the Shrek franchise.Â 

My only criticism is with the villain character of Jack Horner. He was by no means bad - in fact, he had a lot of great lines and wouldâ€™ve been totally serviceable in any everyday film. But, I felt his character didnâ€™t have as much of a depth as everyone else.Â 

Do not write off this film - thereâ€™s a lot this film offers! Go support it so we get more thoughtful films like this!

Name: The Grand Budapest Hotel
Review: This is the first Wes Anderson film I watched. Now I canâ€™t wait to explore the rest of his filmography! Usually, I donâ€™t like it when a â€œglamorized sheenâ€ is added on a film because it feels a lot more fake to me. The worst version of this in my opinions is in Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull.Â  However, this style elevated the film for me. While the story was great and unique, I was somehow more invested in the style than the story. I couldâ€™ve paid zero attention to the story and still enjoy everything about it.Â  Iâ€™m also now much more invested in the filmography of Ralph Fiennes. I first obviously witnessed him as Voldemort. Then after The Menu and now this film, I bet he has a wild range of performances to explore.Â  The only criticism I have is that this film is basically someone telling a story of someone telling a story about the misadventures of this concierge. This background ended up not really having a reason. I wish this was just straight up about the misadventures of this concierge. It took a while to form the setup and get to the actual story, so it initially felt like a chore to sit through it.

Name: Magic Mike
Review:
Eh.Â 

I pretty much only watched this film because Steven Soderbergh directed it. Iâ€™ve recently been intrigued by his variety of films, and though I have mixed feelings on them Iâ€™m still interested in seeing the rest of his filmography.Â 

Iâ€™ll give this credit for being deeper than just male stripper eye candy. It couldâ€™ve definitely still made a lot of money by just being a male stripper movie starring Channing Tatum and Matthew McConaughey. I just personally needed a more investing story to like it.Â 

Somehow this got two sequels. Iâ€™m not excited to check out the others.

Name: The Black Phone
Review: A solid one-time watch horror thriller.Â  I havenâ€™t seen any of Scott Derricksonâ€™s films before Doctor Strange, so I looked forward to see what he would do in his own root element without the studio interference of the MCU. If his other films are like this, then I definitely look forward to checking them out. (I also wish we could see his version on the sequel to Doctor StrangeÂ because I really did not like what we actually got) Admittedly, horror is my least favorite genre. I didnâ€™t watch horror films until adulthood, so I donâ€™t have a nostalgic connection to them. In addition, mainstream horror can go into supernatural elements, which takes me away from believability. I would never completely shut out a film over its genre (and more people need to have that mindset), but it will take more from me to actually like a horror film.Â  Iâ€™m thankful that the only supernatural element in this film is the black phone schtick. Since the entire premise of the film was around this black phone, I could still feel invested in the film.Â  My favorite part of the film is the brother/sister relationship between the kids. I rarely witness films with a close sibling relationship - they usually involve fighting, or the film focuses more on other relationships. This sibling relationship actually felt real and close. When the brother is missing, we feel emotional about it through the sisterâ€™s response. Most kidnapping films wouldâ€™ve focused on the parentâ€™s reactions, so I appreciated this change.Â  I also like that this film takes place in the 1970s. It genuinely feels like we are in that timeframe as we are watching.Â  Overall, it followed all the right beats. Well acted, didnâ€™t jump the shark, stayed thrilling through the runtime. It did what it needed to do. Not amazing enough to rave about, but Iâ€™d definitely recommend a one time watch.Â  Sidebar - Itâ€™s interesting that the marketing focused on the film starring Ethan Hawke. His screen time is not as long, and even when he is around he has a mask. Maybe this was just a marketing stunt to throw a known name on a film?

Name: Violent Night
Review:
Sigh.Â 

Die Hard with David Harbour as Santa. This premise should just write itself. I shouldâ€™ve loved everything about this. Unfortunately, the more I was watching, the more frustrating I got at the choices this film made.Â 

Is this a film for kids? Is this a film for adults? Is this a vulgar, gorey film? Is this a comedy? Is this a heartfelt Christmas film? It feels like the filmmakers tried to say â€œyesâ€ to all of the above, rather than committing to one of them.Â 

I just couldnâ€™t get over the various inconsistencies in this film. For example, a father tells his daughter that Santa isnâ€™t real and that her parents bought all her Christmas gifts. Soon after, Santa shared that he gave this child toys a couple years prior. How is that supposed to be possible? How could we let things like that slide?

There are also a lot of plot armor elements. Santaâ€™s magic works and doesnâ€™t work when the plot needs it to happen. All Home Alone homages are suddenly stitched together into one scene.Â 

Other than Santa and the kid, none of the characters are likable at all. Even the hostages. You need to like the hostages if you want us to care about their safety.Â 

There were also a lot of dimly lit scenes that made it hard to parse what was happening.Â 

Keeping one star because David Harbour as Santa is perfect casting and there are heartfelt moments between him and the kid. Other than that, nothing is redeemable here.Â 

Maybe I wouldâ€™ve enjoyed more if I saw it in a theater with an obnoxious audience that laughs/claps at everything.

Name: Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse
Review: So much hype from start to finish.Â  My background with this franchise is pretty interesting. When I first heard that they were making an animated Spider-Man movie, I was frustrated. We had the Raimi trilogy that I enjoyed, then the Amazing Spider-Man films that I didnâ€™t like (although I appreciated Andrew Garfield), and then finally we got Spider-Man into the MCU. And I really liked Tom Holland as Spider-Man. I really didnâ€™t want more iterations of Spider-Man, and wished we could just let the MCU Spider-Man shine. 2018 was also interesting because we got Venom which I didnâ€™t like (especially because this also meant Venom wouldnâ€™t be in the MCU). And specific to the Into the Spider-Verse trailers, I really didnâ€™t get it - is it just redoing Spider-Man but without Peter Parker as the lead? Once I heard Into the Spider-Verse was actually getting stellar reviews, I was shocked. I watched it in theaters - I definitely laughed, but overall I felt down the middle. Wasnâ€™t disappointed, but also wasnâ€™t mindblown.Â  I then watched this movie again on Netflix couple months later - thatâ€™s when I fell in love with the film. I think I didnâ€™t like it initially because I kept thinking about how I didnâ€™t want more Spider-Man reboots, and didnâ€™t stop to just appreciate the unique art and emotional depth.Â  As much as I would give the first film a 5/5, I actually wasnâ€™t super excited about Across the Spider-Verse as much as other films coming out this year. I was skeptical about the sequel actually feeling fresh compared to the original.Â  From the first scene, it was clear that this film was going to be iconic. The art style is absolutely beautiful. In a similar and completely different manner than Dune, every shot of this film can be blown up into a beautiful art piece. There are altering art styles that somehow work perfectly. It also genuinely feels like reading a comic book. 5 years after the first film, itâ€™s clear that a lot of love went into the art and that is so appreciated.Â  There are so many characters in this film, but each and every one of them are well realized. I clearly understood each of their motivations, and why they do the actions that they do.Â  I also enjoyed the multiverse aspect of this film. I actually want to explore this multiverse further (as opposed to what we got in Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness). It explains well how every world with Spider-Man follows similar tropes but each world has a unique flavor as well.Â  Above all else, the story was super investing. I was just on the ride the whole time and felt the surprising twists at all the right moments. I nearly teared up at all the emotional beats.Â  I appreciate that this film will provide enjoyment even upon rewatches. The pace is so fast, which keeps you on your feet the whole time. However, Iâ€™m sure there are details I missed that I will observe on another rewatch.Â  Yes, this film ends abruptly to set up the next film (another interesting comparison to Dune). I know a lot of people will hate this. My personal view is that as long as the current film was an enjoyable journey, I donâ€™t care about it only being a â€œPart 1â€. And I absolutely enjoyed this journey. I just hope it ends well (and I trust the creative team to do this).Â  The theater I watched the film at was handing out free posters for the film to everyone. Never saw that before. Definitely increased my enjoyment in this theater experience.

Name: Three Thousand Years of Longing
Review: LOL.Â  I generally rate films higher than I should if it takes a risky and unique approach and doesnâ€™t execute it terribly. I donâ€™t expect this film to work for most people, but it worked well enough for me.Â  75% of the film is Idris Elba as a Djinn reciting his years of life story to Tilda Swinton, while 25% of the film is about Tilda Swintonâ€™s life. Most critics seemed to like the 25% part and hate the 75% part. Iâ€™m the opposite - I liked the 75% part and was bored by the 25% part.Â  I could watch Idris Elbaâ€™s Djinn narrate his life story for hours. Usually, narration reduces the impact of scenes. But, Idris Elbaâ€™s delivery juxtaposed with the randomest life events was super amusing to me. If they were instead normal scenes with normal dialogue, I donâ€™t think I wouldâ€™ve been as invested. I didnâ€™t need connective tissue or a â€œso whatâ€ to all this - Iâ€™d be blindly along the journey. It reminded me of those Cars shorts where Mater recites moments of his past life to Lightning McQueen.Â  Gotta dock 1.5 stars for the very normal 25% of film that I wasnâ€™t invested in.

Name: Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me
Review:
Eh.Â 

During this watch, I probably wouldâ€™ve enjoyed this a lot more if I didnâ€™t watch the first film so recently. (Iâ€™m watching the Austin Powers movies quickly before they leave Netflix). 
Iâ€™ll add to my rating to buffer for this.Â 

My feelings are generally the same as the first one. I like the characters of Austin Powers and Dr. Evil, and some moments are truly hilarious. Didnâ€™t feel much about other things. I also felt more tired with the raunchiness nature.

Name: Pitch Perfect 2
Review: Another fun ride! The characters and the acapella really elevate this franchise for me above other similar genre films. All the side characters are basically just described by their one trait, and jokes for that trait get reused through the runtime. Personally, I felt they were all well-timed and well-delivered jokes so I didnâ€™t mind it. They almost got to an overused amount though - I understand if it tipped to overused levels for others though.Â  In the first film, I acknowledged that there were some subplots that didnâ€™t get fully realized, but it didnâ€™t affect my appreciation for the film. However, it did affect me for this film. For example, thereâ€™s a subplot Anna Kendrick trying to pursue a music producer future with Keegan Michael-Key (who was hilarious by the way). It had interesting aspects, but it wasnâ€™t cleanly executed with the overall story. I do see myself rewatching this again sometime.

Name: Rocky Balboa
Review:
Another solid film in the franchise!

Kudos to Sylvester Stallone for making 6 movies in the franchise thus far, with each them feeling some level of justification. Â Each one has had a unique enough aspect worth exploring with another film.Â 

This portrayed in a realistic manner where a successful athlete would be at age 60. Retired. Owning a business. Depressed over the loss of a loved one. 

In particular, I really liked the portrayal of nepotism effects with his son - the son is distant because he wants to not live in his fatherâ€™s shadow anymore but canâ€™t escape it. This brought my favorite scene, when Rocky gives a speech to him about how he should fight through it. It was delivered very consistently with Rockyâ€™s character type too.Â 

Killing off the character of Adrian is risky, but it actually turned out very well here. It led to exploring the sadness of Rocky, and then his rejuvenation when he is ultimately back into boxing.Â 
Iâ€™m also very happy with the characterization of Marie. She easily couldâ€™ve just been the next love interest for Rocky, but thankfully they didnâ€™t go that path. They stayed as a platonic relationship where both sides had something to gain from it, and kept the honor of Adrian through it all. Opposite gender roles in films almost always are romantic, so kudos to this film for going a different route.Â 

Seeing this film in 2023 made the computer aspect super hilarious. â€œIf an athlete from the past fought against an athlete from the present, who would win?â€ is undoubtedly a ChatGPT question. And version 6 of ChatGPT will likely produce a play-by-play visual of this fake fight.Â 

Without spoilers - apparently another cut of this film had the end result of the fight go in the opposite direction, and it actually ended with the same reaction from Rocky. That makes perfect sense, since Rockyâ€™s motivation here is very different from prior films.Â 

The main part that really set this back for me was the direction of the final fight. It felt like they just had a shot of every default filter available in the video editing system and used it. The best part of the past fights were that it felt like we were watching real people doing real fighting. Here, it felt so dramatized and took away all tension for me.Â 

Another minor setback for me was the character of Paulie. He was never my favorite in the franchise. But here, his inclusion felt very inconsistent and took away from the other strong aspects of the film.Â 

It seems this film was really praised at the time of its release because of the big gap between films (especially when people thought Rocky V is the last film) and that Stalloneâ€™s career really stagnated around this time so Rocky and Stallone followed similar character arcs. I totally understand that, but years later new fans of the franchise may not have this impact to elevate their feelings. Not really a pro or con here, but felt it was worth acknowledging.

Name: Freaky
Review:
Amazing premise, frustrating execution (no pun intended)

I was ready to give this a 5/5. A slasher with a body-swapping schtick is a hilarious concept, and Vince Vaughn and Kathryn Newton are perfect casting as the serial killer and high school student. Unfortunately, too many inconsistencies kept pulling me away. I began the film about to give a 5/5, and then I ended the film with just barely recommending it.

The opening film is actually very creepy - A+ introduction. The rest of the film ends up being a less serious tone. While initially feeling odd, this does make sense. A serial killer & high school student getting a body-swap will obviously not keep this serious of a tone.

The part they really nailed are the performances of Vince Vaughn and Kathryn Newton. Vince Vaughn can appear creepy, and also acts very well as a teenage girl. Kathryn Newton looks perfect as a teenage girl, and plays well with how a serial killer would act as her body. As expected, they utilize the Vince Vaughn body as a fear and Kathryn Newton as a seemingly innocent person well.

Obviously films will have coincidences happen, but there were so many here to the point of unbelievability. I started getting turned off when the woodshop high school teacher straight up acts like an asshole to Kathryn Newton, to the point where that woodshop teacher should get fired for his actions. 
The point that I lost it is soon after the body-swap happens. Kathryn Newton was set up as someone that doesn't put effort into her looks. But post body-swap, she ties her hair in a perfect ponytail and has model-level makeup and lipstick on. Would a Vince Vaughn type actually know how to put handle cosmetics??
If these were the only coincidences, I could ignore it. But, there's a new coincidence happening every 5 minutes so that made it hard to believe.

Totally unrelated to my review - Kathryn Newton's character is a super fan of Pitch Perfect 2 and has a poster of it in her bedroom. I just recently watched Pitch Perfect 2...

Name: The Peanut Butter Falcon
Review: A feel-good film with a couple great scenes and incredible performance from Zack Gottsagen.Â  The best part of this is how the character of Zak, a person with Down Syndrome, is handled. Itâ€™s the perfect combination of acknowledging he has a disability, while also not treating him with pity. We understand why he wants freedom, but we also obviously know that the world will be tough for him and want to protect him. How do we handle this? The film nicely shows how to do this.Â  Zakâ€™s happiness is truly infectious. Anytime he is happy, everyone will be happy.Â  Tyler and Zakâ€™s chemistry is also charming. Tyler is obviously a flawed person, but his behavior towards Zak is heartwarming. He treats Zak like a normal person, but will defend him against the worldâ€™s attacks.Â  Thereâ€™s a lot of conveniences to make this story go itâ€™s directions. (We just accept that Eleanor knocks on the same doors as Tyler soon after?). But unlike my prior watched film Freaky, the conveniences didnâ€™t take away from the intended feelings with the film. It does prevent me from raving about it though.Â  I also wouldâ€™ve liked to see more about the backstory of Tyler. The film shows moments of flashbacks, and makes us make assumptions on how those moments resolve and result in the Tyler we see on film. But, actually showing the resolution of those moments wouldâ€™ve been powerful.

Name: Austin Powers in Goldmember
Review:
A couple hilarious sequences with Austin Powers and Dr. Evil, but overall too much.Â 

The opening of this film is absolute perfection. Didnâ€™t see that coming at all. Unfortunately, there were only a couple sequences that stuck the landing as well as the opening.Â 

One thing I generally applaud with this series is that the quality is consistent through all three films. Each one has great one-liners, and each one also has sequences that go a couple lines longer than it should. I think there is a 5/5 star version of an Austin Powers film that has aspects of all three films. This version would focus more on smart humor and less on raunchy humor.Â 

Yes, definitely many moments that donâ€™t age well. I wouldnâ€™t mark this against the film, but I would add this as a caution before having a newbie watch something in this series.Â 

Definitely fun seeing BeyoncÃ© though.Â 

As much as I feel down the middle through these three films, I would look forward to a fourth reunion film.

Name: Adipurush
Review: ğŸ¤¦ğŸ¾â€â™‚ï¸Â  Itâ€™s really frustrating that the filmmakers were given a giant budget to make Ramayana with modern visual effects, but deviated so much from the source material. I briefly read through production details to try to understand what they were going for. Did they try to adapt Ramayana but decided to add some creative additions to be different? Or did they want a different story with inspiration from Ramayana? It seems that â€œYesâ€ was answered to both questions at different points, and that really showed in the film. Committing to either direction wouldâ€™ve let me move this rating to the positive direction. But the inconsistencies were too apparent.Â  Very odd choice to not call any of the characters by their known names. Itâ€™s not Ram and Sita, but Raghava and Janaki. Same goes for every character here. Literally no reason to do this.Â  The vibe of this world is also frustrating. The whole setting was darkly lit with dark colors (other than one scene). Ramayana is supposed to have a bright and positive feel (even if battles exist).Â  Then, Sri Lanka for some reason was visualized with a Gotham-like feel. Completely opposite setting to the jungle vibe of India. It truly felt like I was watching two different movies.Â  All of the above was my commentary on the frustrations around deviations from the source material. But even with the lens of not knowing the source material, thereâ€™s a lot wrong here.Â  I usually donâ€™t comment on bad acting, but Prabhas was horribly miscast here. He had an emotionless state the entire time and no charisma. All the inspiration to feel in this film depends on him as the leader, and he did not deliver.Â  There was a huge reliance on showing off CGI. While I understand that Indian film CGI is nowhere near on the level as American film CGI, the focus shouldâ€™ve moved towards character development than on visuals.Â  Not many positives but Iâ€™ll list them: - The score is good, even if it is overplayed a lot.Â  - I would love to see Saif Ali Khan as a super villain character in a comic book film someday. His villain performance here was better than many supervillains Iâ€™ve seen recently. (Unfortunately, it was nothing like Ravana so that frustrated me) - 3 hour runtime, but it didnâ€™t totally feel that long. I didnâ€™t really have the urge to check the time or truly feel itâ€™s length.Â  I really donâ€™t understand how you can have such a budget but go so off direction of what audiences need from a historical epic.

Name: 12 Years a Slave
Review: A jaw-dropping, shocking view into the world of slavery.Â  This film really makes you a fly on the wall through the brutality that existed in this time. Canâ€™t believe how disgusting slave-owners acted, and how they treated slaves as property and not people.Â  The scenes that really hurt me are the ones where technically brutality could stop if someone just got up and said something. But, all the slave-owners donâ€™t view it as brutality and all the slaves had rightful fear to speak up. I really wished I could jump into the film and stop the madness that I was witnessing.Â  Excellent performances from Michael Fassbender, Chiwetel Ejifor, and Lupita Nyongo (amongst others). They really elevated the film.Â  I remember wishing that The Wolf of Wall Street won the Best Picture Oscar this year. But after seeing this film, Iâ€™m not at all mad about this winning. Very well deserved. Also well deserved Oscar for Lupita Nyongoâ€™s performance and the adapted screenplay.Â  Dropping a half star for a couple nitpicks. Namely, it felt like the passage of time was much less than 12 years. Also, as our main character moved around plantations, there would be some moments that didnâ€™t seem to amount to much. On one hand, if this is a retelling of a true story then itâ€™s not expected for every moment to have a â€œpurposeâ€. On the other hand, it is a film so it should be fair to judge itâ€™s storytelling.

Name: Moonrise Kingdom
Review: Very cute world and journey from the eyes of Wes Anderson.Â  The only Wes Anderson film I saw other than this one is The Grand Budapest Hotel. I donâ€™t know why it took so long for me to start watching his films, because heâ€™s so in line with my guilty pleasures. The vibe is always so goofy and dysfunctional. I donâ€™t need to watch his films with a close studying eye (even if there is a lot to analyze) because I can just relax and enjoy the journey, while at the same time I really shouldnâ€™t multitask while watching his films in case I miss a great one-liner.Â  Another thing I noticed that I love about his films is despite there being A-listers, each actor truly encompasses a character in the Wes Anderson world. So I see the film more as a goofy film than the actors playing their characters.Â  On rom-com standards, this stands out above the rest by a mile. First off, I fully understood why the main characters wanted to leave their lives to be together. Most rom-coms donâ€™t put focus on why you should believe the leads should be together (other than they are the main characters and are attractive). The leads here had a lot of pain in their lives, and found solace in each other through that terrible pain. So even though they did a sorta immature task of running away, I rooted for them.
