It is surprising that this film was directed by Neill Blomkamp because this film is a completely different genre from his past works. Usually when this happens, it's done for the sake of getting a quick paycheck and allowing a lot of studio interference to occur. But here, I felt there was a lot of great creative choices from the director that a quick paycheck job would not have done. I can't wait to see more from this director, and I hope studios allow more filmmakers to make genre pivots like this.

I have many flaws due to the amount that the film resorted to conventional sports drama norms (which I will get into soon), but the highs of this film are so high that the lows don't set it back too far for me.

My list of flaws:
Jann's parents should've had more of an inclusion in the film. Given that the film shows the parents as closely caring for Jann, it's odd that they don't even show up in person to some of his races.
In addition, Jann's dad should've had more of the emotional support rather than focusing on David Harbour's support.
The romance subplot seriously did not need to exist. Not much chemistry there, and all the emotional weight that the filmmakers thought would come from this could've instead come from the parents.
There is an emotional scene between Jann and David Harbour's character that covered the backstory of David Harbour's character. The scene was properly emotional. But realistically, this character is an athlete, so Jann easily could've looked up his backstory at any point rather than being shocked by hearing about it in this moment.

Overall, I wish I saw this in theaters. I also wish more people watched this film in theaters. Yes, there were a lot of trailers for this film before it's release that made you feel like you already saw the whole movie just from the trailers, but the film followed all the right beats that made the journey great.

Name: Ma
Review:
Octavia Spencerâ€™s amazing performance elevates this everyday psychological horror film into a time-pass.Â 

Iâ€™ve always loved Octavia Spencer and sheâ€™s had well-deserved praise from all her other films, but this film really showcased to me how talented she is. This film is so out of her league, itâ€™s like this film just doesnâ€™t deserve her talent.Â 
Iâ€™ve never seen a creepy side to her, and wow was she very creepy.Â 

The first half of this film was actually solid for me, I was ready to rate it my best score. All the high schoolers behaved believably - of course a free hangout spot for alcohol is attractive. The unsettling moments were heightening in the right ways. The character of Ma had the right amount of mystery to be curious what drives her motivations.Â 

The second half unfortunately derailed heavily. Character choices became very inconsistent - for example, a person was very scared of Ma in one scene, and then oddly not scared anymore in the next. There were many moments where the film couldâ€™ve just ended with a quick 911 call, but they avoid that direction with stupid character choice. The last scene is absolutely bad shit crazy in the stupidest ways.Â 

Despite leaving with a bad taste, I still canâ€™t get over Octavia Spencerâ€™s amazing performance. The film is definitely worth a watch just for that.

Name: May December
Review:
Obviously Iâ€™m this involved in film because I love watching all types of films. However, Iâ€™ve never really aligned well with what tends to the be on the â€œbest of the yearâ€ lists. Some are amazing to me, most feel like overrated Oscar bait. Itâ€™s also odd to me that most of these â€œbest of the yearâ€ films are released at the end of the year along with Oscar campaigns, like weâ€™re supposed to expect that these will be one of the best films to watch. Then we totally forget about it after awards season.Â 
All to say - this is the mentality I go into when watching Oscar bait films like this one.Â 

As I was watching this film, I genuinely really hated the journey due to its gross subject matter, and an odd appearance that all the characters refer to this huge age-gap relationship as just a fact that exists and not as disturbing. My immediate thought was that there should be less films like this in the world, and more films around actual entertainment. Â 

Admittedly, I found myself thinking about this film days after the watch. I found myself reading upon the real life story that this film is loosely based on. I appreciated the choice of incorporating a method actor in the mix, as it showed the dangers of method acting. I then also understood the perspective of child who experienced abuse but didnâ€™t really grasp it as abuse until the events that we see in the film. All in all, it was a unique choice to not focus on the events of child abuse, but focusing on ramifications of a child abuse episode many years later.Â 
All of these juxtaposed together are very risky choices that somehow work together well, mainly due to great acting across the board.Â 

Still, I do not recommend watching this movie. Iâ€™d rather feel unsettled in horror, rather than unsettled in child abuse drama. Most people will not relate to these characters.Â 
I guess the best praise I can give this film is that I can understand this film getting awards buzz (just given how film awards bs goes). Personally, I wish we lived in a world where the many other films this year can get awards consideration because they will connect more with audiences and not be forgotten outside of awards season.

Name: The Creator
Review: A thoroughly refreshing original sci-fi world! This is the type of film we need to see more of, and the type of film that audiences need to support in theaters.Â  The best part of this film is undoubtedly the world-building. The film begins with a lot of exposition about the rules of the world, but it didnâ€™t feel like an exposition dump. In fact, quite the opposite. The entire look of the film was so unique that I was looking forward to learn more about it. Through the film, certain actions take place (e.g. transferring brain into some sort of thumb drive to be experienced through a machine) which are fascinating and totally make sense in this world. I genuinely believed I lived in a world where AI technology existed for many years (e.g. temple architecture crafted with AI entities).Â  Visuals are absolutely breathtaking. Here is proof that huge budgets are unnecessary to get immersed. Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny apparently had a budget over three times this one, but this film had way more believable set pieces and action sequences.Â  I genuinely do not understand the criticisms that this film is derivative of many other sci-fi plots. Maybe if I squint I could find some similarities, but I feel like Iâ€™m just pulling at strings when I do that. The world is so unique and unlike other films Iâ€™ve seen, so that alone made my experience very positive.Â  Most films that tackle AI show how terrible it is and that it must be stopped. Without spoiling much, we get perspectives here that are much more of a gray area (despite an entire AI war going on). So that goes to show that there is uniqueness offered in the film.Â  Performances from Madeleine Yuna Voyles and John David Washington were amazing, and truly elevated this film.Â  My only criticism was that especially in the second half, there are many conveniently timed actions to allow certain plot points and sequences to occur.Â  I also will note there were cases where I totally missed some lines of important dialogue so I didnâ€™t fully follow how certain plot points occurred. I donâ€™t fault the film for this, I personally do this very often *facepalm*

Name: The Killer
Review:
Thereâ€™s a lot of uniqueness in this film to appreciate. I canâ€™t think of any other film like this!

I was surprised with how engrossed I was in this movie, despite lacking much action or fast pace. Itâ€™s also very admirable, considering that most of the film is just voiceover.Â 

I think what I really appreciated was that I got to see a completely different perspective to a character we see a lot of in action movies. We see the whole process that goes into a killer preparing for a murder, and not just the murder. In a way, this is a perfect fit for David Fincher since he is such a methodical director too. 
I also really like that the overall plot and premise was kept pretty simple. More complexities wouldâ€™ve removed the charm for me.Â 

The film somehow also gets away with not requiring much character background explanation to feel invested. We are told just enough information about the characters, and yet at the same time we donâ€™t want to learn more because the mystery is more captivating.Â 

This film also had a lot of dark comedy that really landed well for me.Â 

I think most people would be disappointed with this film because they expect a lot of action based on the title alone.Â 

My only complaint is that some scenes went on a bit longer than I wouldâ€™ve liked. In a way I guess the long scenes are â€œaccurateâ€ because killers are supposed to wait until the right time for a murder. But as a viewer, this was still something that caught my attention.

Name: The Lighthouse
Review: A surprisingly fun and scary contained film.Â  I admittedly had low expectations going into this one. The premise seemed boring to me, and the black-and-white choice added to me feeling uninterested. I chose to give it a shot because I absolutely loved another film this director created - The Northman.Â  My biggest praise is how many risks this film took. Itâ€™s a black-and-white, nearly square aspect ratio, set before the 1900s, and only has two cast members in a lighthouse. Despite all these â€œrestrictionsâ€, there was so much to explore in the world. I never felt like this was an actually old film, because it was paced well and had a lot of stimulus going on.Â  I also donâ€™t think that any of these choices were just checkboxes to stand out; they actually enhanced the best parts of the film. For example, light from a lighthouse feels even more blinding with just the contrast from black and white compared to what can be done with color. I really appreciate filmmaking that goes outside of conventions with a purpose.Â  Another thing that worked for me well is the time period choice. It allowed me to be *more accepting* of barbaric and crazy actions. If this was a modern setting, uncivilized natures wouldnâ€™t make as much sense to me. Also, this time period brought the best vocabulary from the lines of Willem Dafoe, which was so funny to watch.Â  This film does the best job Iâ€™ve seen of blending comedy with psychological horror. Just horror elements are not my personal taste because it makes the film journey unsettling. Blending comedy made this a fascinating and unique experience.Â  The two leads were perfectly cast here. Iâ€™d argue that this film has the best performances from both Robert Pattinson and Willem Dafoe. The love-hate relationship between them was so adorable.Â  There probably is a lot to analyze within this film - I bet thereâ€™s lots of references to mythologies. And I think this is why some scenes and details lingered on slightly more than Iâ€™d want to.

Name: Black Swan
Review: This was not my cup of tea, but Iâ€™m not mad about this movie being so acclaimed - I actually understand why people love it.Â  The best part is definitely the cinematography. The camera work that sifted through the ballerina dance sequences were remarkable, I have no idea how that was filmed so perfectly.Â  I also will commend Natalie Portman, definitely her best performance and she deserves all the praise for it.Â  Personally, the whole time I couldnâ€™t help but compare this to Whiplash, which I feel is a much better version of what this film wanted to communicate. I felt this film included too many unnecessary details (e.g. sexual subplots, an overarching horror element). While on the other hand, WhiplashÂ stuck to the main story and didnâ€™t overcomplicate through the runtime.Â  But, I did see another review that described Whiplash as the masculine version and this film as the feminine version. I could totally follow, so I can understand if people love this film but hate Whiplash.Â  Iâ€™m sure thereâ€™s a lot to analyze and appreciate within the themes of what the play is based on, and how it reflected into the main characters of the film. But, I just donâ€™t care enough about exploring that. Admittedly, Iâ€™m someone that never cared about analyzing all the books we read through English classes, so this could just be a byproduct of that. I bet most audiences would appreciate it more than me.

Name: Hi Nanna
Review:
I hate bucketing films of a certain genre or language and claiming all of them are the same. But, this film follows the same pitfalls as many Indian films I watch. Open with an interesting premise, go absolutely ludicrous and conventional directions in the end.Â 

The film opens with a father that has a child with cystic fibrosis. Everything about this relationship through the film is absolutely heartwarming. This setup alone was enough for me to be ready for the journey, even if it could go a predictable route.Â 

Frustratingly, the film decides to incorporate every over-the-top romance genre twist into the mix. We got an amnesia episode, someone needing to decide between two people to settle down with, walking away from the alter, and so much more. Itâ€™s almost like the film occasionally forgets about the cystic fibrosis element, to ensure thereâ€™s time for the typical film tropes.

Name: Shastry Viruddh Shastry
Review: I would describe this as a more relatable and better watch than Marriage Story.Â  Iâ€™ve grown up watching English, Hindi, and Telugu movies. I think itâ€™s common knowledge that Hollywood movies have more international attention. Many perceive Hollywood as being â€œbetterâ€ - I donâ€™t fully agree, but I understand why this happens. Hollywood movies generally do a better job of showing instead of telling, and are more sharply edited. Despite this, something still appeals me to still keep watching Indian movies. This film is a good example of why I feel this way.Â  This film covers a topic of how to properly handle childcare amongst working parents and grandparents. A Hollywood version of this would not have appealed to me at all. It wouldâ€™ve had parents that have no close relationships to their grandparents. It wouldâ€™ve had divorced parents. Overall, they wouldâ€™ve included unnecessary subplots and take away from the childcare focus.Â  Yes, this film shows tension amongst the parents and grandparents about how to care for the child. But, what I truly appreciated about this film is that there was never a sense of hatred. Despite the arguments, you could feel that everyone still had a familial love and respect for each other. As difficult as childcare is, no one saw it as a burden to care for the child. In this way, the film was very realistic.Â  I couldâ€™ve done away with some other subplots that the film provided, and I wouldâ€™ve preferred that the tension was just focused on the childcare topic. But other than that, this is a great watch.

Name: Self Reliance
Review:
Cool concept, executed in an uninteresting way.Â 

I had no idea this movie existed until a few minutes before starting this movie on Hulu.Â 

The concept is definitely intriguing. Iâ€™m kinda surprised a movie concept like this hasnâ€™t existed before. I was on board with most of the plot points, and I appreciated keeping this in a small scale.Â 

Unfortunately, the journey itself wasnâ€™t that fun. I wish there were more interesting twists, a faster pace, and better quality jokes.

Name: Hanu-Man
Review: What an enjoyable Â and fresh superhero journey! I admittedly had very low expectations going into this. I was kinda put off by a superhero spin about Hanuman - the last time we saw a version of this was Adipurush, which was such a dumpster-fire and disrespectful to the Hindu gods.Â  I was very pleasantly surprised by the fact that this actually worked! Iâ€™m thankful that there was actually faithfulness and respect to Hanuman, the Hindu god. I think this film can make people more fascinated to learn about Hanuman, which is a very good thing.Â  My favorite part is that despite this being a superhero movie, it broke many of the genre conventions in the best ways. As much as Iâ€™m a bigger defender of the MCU compared to the average person, I am pretty sick of all of them doing the same thing again and again. Thereâ€™s a sloppily formed villain, a third act battle with many explosions and the entire fate of the universe is very close to imploding until a certain convenience.Â  This film chose to keep it contained to a small town, which paid off so well here. No reason to switch to other cities in the world, because all the heart exists in this small town. We become a part of the characters in the town, so we genuinely feel fear when they are in danger. All the nature and buildings feel so real, so we really get frustrated when destruction happens.Â  The villain was also much more relatable. Sure, he had his token evil laughter moments, but his backstory was actually well developed to not feel like a token villain.Â  Here is also a good example of how inflated budgets are so unnecessary. Sure, you could look at the special effects at face value and say that they are subpar at best. But, once you look at the budget, itâ€™s actually admirable how much they did with visual effects. Many films with higher budgets are basically to the star power for some reason.Â  There was a lot of fun humor around our protagonist getting his powers. It was a genuine and charming type of humor that I just donâ€™t really see in Hollywood.Â  I could nitpick this film a lot more for things like improper editing, but I donâ€™t really see the need. The highs of this film are so high, that these details didnâ€™t take away from my joy with the film.Â  The only actual criticism Iâ€™ll have is that it included a lot of the worst tropes of Telugu masala movies. Thereâ€™s inappropriate humor which is really out of place. The main actress is showcased as a model, and focuses less on the actual good she does for the community.Â  This was the first time I saw a film where the word â€œCGIâ€ was imprinted on the bottom left of the screen any time we saw animals. I donâ€™t understand why this is required - the rule should just be to add a blurb at the beginning that says â€œno animals were harmed in the making of this filmâ€ or something. It kept taking me away out of the film. Also, the â€œCGI animalsâ€ were actually very realistic in most scenes - kudos to the visual effects artists.

Name: Polite Society
Review: Imagine Scott Pilgrim vs. the World vibes, with a high schooler trying to be a stuntwoman and saving her sister.Â  I usually cringe at films created outside of the India/Pakistan industry but have main characters of that descent. It always holds people that hate their heritage and have the worst rebellious nature.Â  But, thankful that none of that cringe existed here. It utilized the right levels of heritage references without making it an unnecessarily shoehorned part of the plot. And I believed that the characters actually act the way they do.Â  My favorite part was the comedy of this film. It had the right blend of silliness and timing to all feel smart. It reminded me a lot of Cobra Kai, where random drama elements turn into huge fighting set pieces that are actually well crafted.Â  I like that it starts out somewhat realistically in that the main character is trying to find the thorn in her sister going away for marriage, but at the surface there is nothing wrong. It seemed to perfectly capture the fear of a sibling when an older sibling goes for marriage, scared that the sibling relationship will not be the same again.Â  I also appreciate the uniqueness - I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ll ever see an Indian stuntwoman film again. And that too, especially with high school immaturity and silliness.Â  Especially with the third act, plot details got way too ludicrous. Definitely did not take away from my appreciation for the film, but I wish these parts were more sharply edited.

Name: Call Me by Your Name
Review:
Here is a great example of where I really donâ€™t align with the traditional film critics.Â 

The only thing I can really appreciate is the setting. I love the setting of a small town in Italy. Too many times we see films take place in the same cities abroad, so it was refreshing to be a part of this fresh setting.Â 

Other than that, nothing worked for me here. I frankly see this as â€œartisticâ€ erotic romance. I donâ€™t understand how this romance was viewed as beautiful and endearing. Personally for me, romance is endearing when it focuses on the emotional gain between the two people. I donâ€™t relate when the romance focuses a lot on physical moments and sexual references. And I especially donâ€™t relate when there is a strong variation in maturity between the two people.

Name: Society of the Snow
Review:
Absolutely speechless.Â 

I cannot believe this actually happened. I read up everything about this story afterwards, and Iâ€™m so shook by it. Iâ€™m so glad that this film stayed faithful to the real story in every way, keeping all the plot points and harrowing moments. It was faithful even in casting actors of the proper backgrounds and using the proper Uruguayan Spanish dialect.Â 

I felt breathless through the whole runtime. In a matter of seconds, the situation went from fun and games to mortal fear. The plane crash scene was absolutely scary (even when you remove the fact that this actually happened). I felt the blinding and chilling pain that the characters felt. I think this was because they set up well that the characters are literally just everyday people. Anyone can see themselves as any of the passengers of that plane. No one can be prepared for such a moment.Â 

What I truly appreciated was that they didnâ€™t go a traditional film star survival route here. There wasnâ€™t really a main character in the film. This added to the feeling that literally anyone could be the next person could die. Within a blink of the eye, even the physically and mentally strongest person can lose their life in this situation.Â 
In addition, there wasnâ€™t â€œthat one idiot characterâ€ in the mix. Everyone acted as a team player. So I could stay actually rooting for everyone.Â 

Even though this film follows the same plot points as the true story, I wonâ€™t spoil anything here. But, this film brings up ethical questions and I followed the same exact arc that the characters did. Pretty fascinating that the film could match my feelings as I was watching it.Â 

This was a long film, but unlike most films of 2023 I agreed with the length of this film. It almost felt like my duty to suffer through the visuals, given that all the people had to live through those conditions for an unknown number of days.

Name: 12th Fail
Review:
A unique tale into the world of cop recruitment.

I connected to every plot point that this film went through. The humble beginnings from someone in a small town to become an IPS officer. It went through all the steps in a natural manner that makes sense. 

For some reason, many Indian films portray the cops in a gross, corrupt manner. While some of that is here, the film shows the police department in a respectful manner and how the best cops will be rewarded properly. This was very refreshing. 
I also had no idea that it's this difficult to be a part of the police in India. There are so many exams and specific steps to go through, along with the ability to write thorough exams on specific topics. 

I really liked the motivation of the protagonist to become successful. One experience with a just police officer inspired him to stay faithful through the rest of his journey. This was very believable given his background. It was also cute to see his family get so excited with his successes. I rooted for him consistently through the runtime.

There were a few moments that could've been edited more sharply. Some scenes went on a bit longer than they needed to. But other than that, this was a great watch!

Name: Dumb Money
Review: A fun retelling of the weird Gamestonk moment in 2021.Â  I weirdly have a soft spot for movies that cover a news story that I actually remember happening. The first time I remember that happening was for Sully, and now again for this film.Â  The film showcases the funniest parts of the news story well. The fact that it was all Reddit users with their non-PC meme personas rallying everyday people to make Wall Street investors broke is such a hilarious concept. That being said, it leans a bit more into some of these than I wouldâ€™ve liked.Â  I canâ€™t help feel like this wouldâ€™ve been much better as a documentary though. Cool to see A-listers I guess, but the impact wouldâ€™ve been better for me if I heard from the actual people getting interviewed and showing their experiences.Â  Overall, I laughed at the right moments and felt the correct emotions that the film wanted me to feel, so thatâ€™s good!

Name: Pain Hustlers
Review: This was overall a nice time-pass film with a solid Emily Blunt performance.Â  I approved of all the major plot points this goes through. I could believe that someone who is between jobs is suddenly successful in pharmaceutical sales. Obviously a plot like this will have a rise and then a fall, but the journey was investing enough.Â  It is pretty jarring that things like this unfortunately occur in the pharmaceutical industry. Given how terrible its effects are on the addicted patients, a part of me wishes that the film had some more depressing images of its effects. The whole film has more of a â€œfunâ€ tone like The Wolf of Wall Street, which makes for a fun journey, but I ultimately question if the tonal choice fits well.Â  Huge respect for director David Yates for branching out of the Harry PotterÂ franchise that heâ€™s been pigeonholed into.Â  I think another issue is that some parts here felt edited improperly. For example, at the beginning, Andy Garciaâ€™s character gets crazily paranoid near the end, but it almost felt like a completely different character trait from what we saw in the beginning. Another example is that Emily Bluntâ€™s daughter was very prominent at the beginning, and then not shown much later. Just one of these wouldâ€™ve been fine, but multiple instances added up together to get an odd feeling.Â  I was also not a fan of Catherine Oâ€™Haraâ€™s inclusion. Obviously she is talented and has fun moments, but I think it deviated improperly from the best parts of the film.Â  Overall, it was a fun journey and I did learn something new about how the pharmaceutical companies can get away with their behaviors. So that brings a positive recommendation from me.

Name: Saltburn
Review: There were moments when I watched this film and wanted to switch it off, thinking it was one of the worst movies Iâ€™ve ever seen. And right when Iâ€™d want to do that, a new plot point emerged that seemed interesting to make me enjoy it. This continued through the runtime. I will acknowledge that this is a very unique film that took many risks so I will appreciate that.Â  The film begins in a fairly heartwarming way, where a kid wants to be friends with the popular guy. I got very interested when it defied coming-of-age film tropes by immediately showing that the popular guy is actually not as douchey as youâ€™d think. The popular guy actually had a strong heart with relatable emotions, genuinely caring about someone not as privileged as him.Â  I got very concerned once they moved into the same house for the summer. I thought this would be like Call Me By Your Name, where it even had the same shared bathroom layout. By the end, I was thankful it didnâ€™t go that route at all.Â  This was really good at landing dark comedy. I couldnâ€™t help but laugh when characters say the worst things at the worst times.Â  Barry Keoghan was a standout performance, he truly gave it everything and shouldâ€™ve deserved an Oscar nomination.Â  I think it really couldâ€™ve done without the overly erotic scenes (except the very last scene, that was hilarious). I didnâ€™t really get the point of those moments, other than make me feel uncomfortable in the worst ways.Â  I was also shocked that the film did a lot of handholding to explain events, rather than leave them implied. It almost felt like the filmmakers thought the audience would be too stupid to make the necessary connections.

Name: The Last Duel
Review: A thought-provoking drama that happens to occur during medieval times.Â  The medieval setting frankly isnâ€™t my favorite because Iâ€™m just not fascinated enough with those vibes. That being said, I still keep an open mind with it because Iâ€™ve thoroughly enjoyed some of them in the past (e.g. The Northman, Game of Thrones) as long as they add something new. And Iâ€™m glad to report that this one definitely did.Â  Ridley Scott as director is enough for me to be interested - he really should be respected on the same caliber as Martin Scorsese and Steven Spielberg. In addition, this was the only screenplay co-written by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck after Good Will Hunting!Â  I admittedly felt like it was fairly slow paced in the first hour or so (despite appreciating the cinematography). It felt like just the typical medieval hero arc of a guy trying to get political power through marriage and gained land.Â  Once the film unfolds its Rashomon effect, thatâ€™s when it gets super interesting. This storytelling device was done so effectively. Despite seeing the same scenes multiple times, seeing them from different perspectives kept it fresh. The new perspectives were both surprising and understandable given the character personalities. The least spoiler version of this is when we first see a marriage scene that appears like all happiness from the husband side. But when we see this from the wife side, it is instead fear.Â  The most fascinating part for me was that we donâ€™t just see each moment from one characterâ€™s perspective. In a way, we as the viewer are forming our neutral perspective based on what we see from the characterâ€™s perspective. So, a character could be doing an action that they believe is normal, but we know is an evil action. This makes us assign the character as evil, but also understanding that the character does not think they are evil.Â  So as such new perspectives became clear, the film became much more fascinating. I retroactively appreciated the first hour a lot more (although it still felt slow).Â  With medieval times comes regressive cultures that exist in the times, and we witnessed unfiltered versions of this. While normally I hate unnecessary graphic scenes, here it made sense for what the film was trying to communicate. It was a huge risk to create a medieval setting without action being the focus, but I think it overall made sense for the story.Â  Despite the A-list cast, Jodie Comer was my favorite performance in the film. Her emotional diversity was executed so perfectly. Her performance in this film perfectly encapsulated why women coming forward on sexual assault allegations is a difficult choice to make.Â  This film unfortunately bombed at the box office, and I think a lot of it was due to timing. It was theatrically released in 2021, when older people still were hesitant about movie theaters. If it came out any other time, I think it couldâ€™ve gotten much better buzz.Â  I wish films like this get more awards attention. Itâ€™s kinda frustrating that there has to be a separate budget to push Oscar consideration because it really doesnâ€™t level the playing field and great films that choose not to be Oscar bait then become unnoticed.

Name: Sound of Freedom
Review:
Note: this film seems to be either critically acclaimed or critically panned, depending on the political leaning of the critic. I really hate it when this happens, and I wish people can do a better job of neutral criticism.Â 

This was a realistic thriller through the disgusting world of child sex trafficking.Â 

What made this film very unique was that it wasnâ€™t over-stylized or â€œglamorizedâ€ in the way that most thrillers are. There is no cool fight scene with the hero all bloodied up and still pushing through. The film covers the planning and tense intrigue through catching the criminals. Some can argue this causes a slow pace, but I think it was a much better choice to do it this way because it was more realistic and it showcased how scary it was to actually conduct these missions.Â 

I also couldnâ€™t help but feel very emotional once the kids were rescued. Any human should get angry through what these kids faced, and feel a huge sense of relief once their pain and suffering is over. The one scene that really got to me was when the kid and his father were reunited.Â 

The one part I wish we got more of is the protagonistâ€™s motivation to commit to these rescue missions. All we get is one arrest and a conversation with a friend to make him decide to sacrifice his own life to these missions. It felt very abrupt. It shouldâ€™ve had more personal situations leading up to this ultimate choice. Or if the true story really was from just those moments, those moments needed to be more throughly realized.Â 

This part is less on the film itself and more on the political conversations around it: I donâ€™t understand why there are controversies. I felt absolutely no political propaganda while watching this film. Stopping child sex trafficking is a unifying apolitical goal.Â 
Iâ€™ve also heard some controversy around the fact that some of the moments represented in the film didnâ€™t actually occur. Even if that is true - there are countless movies based on true stories that take creative liberties to change things up. So if this type of criticism should be made to this film, it should be made to all films that take similar creative liberties.

Name: Yesterday
Review:
What a hidden gem of a film!

I do recall slightly hearing about this film when it came out, but I admittedly knew nothing about it other than it was somehow music related. I got curious to watch it once it came on Prime and I saw the synopsis that seemed the right amount of silly and unique.Â 
Thankfully, this film lived up to its premise!

There was a lot of risk that went into the execution of its premise. It couldâ€™ve focused on just fan service for The Beatles. It couldâ€™ve been a serious tone taking completely realistic plot points. It couldâ€™ve leaned in heavily into the typical teenage coming-of-age conventions. It did none of those, and took a fresh take that I honestly havenâ€™t seen before.Â 

The whole premise is built upon that fact that a worldwide outage removed random things from existence from 99.99% of the population. On paper that seems so ludicrous. But here, it seemed just wacky enough to buy into it and go on board with all the associated choices.Â 
It also didnâ€™t explain how the outage works, which was the right choice because it wasnâ€™t the focus.Â 
Critics seemed to feel like the effects of this outage are not done realistically. Well duh, the whole concept of it is so weird! I feel like focusing on this as a negative is such a nitpick. The choices made were so funny (e.g. singing a Beatles song at a kids birthday = no appreciation) that I didnâ€™t think the realism mattered.Â 

Without spoiling anything, I like that the protagonist didnâ€™t have external forces pushing him away from his decision to capitalize on the music. Most films wouldâ€™ve done this. Instead, the only forces acting against were internal guilt. I feel this film had a lot to show about consequences of actions just from internal forces. I have this feelings personally often, so it was relatable to see it get a focus on screen.Â 

I actually liked all the characters in the film (except Kate McKinnonâ€™s character). That made it investing to watch.Â 

I was also refreshed with a minor choice in the second act. The protagonist and love interest have some scenes where they enjoy each others company and hang out through the city. It sorta signaled that the day would end with the two of them sleeping together, but they ultimately didnâ€™t. It wasnâ€™t shown as a rift in the relationship, but just a choice not executed upon. I wish more films could do this.Â 

Three things Iâ€™d say against the movie:
1) A choice made by the love interest in the second suddenly came out of left field, and I wish it couldâ€™ve been explored further before making that choice.Â 
2) Kate McKinnonâ€™s character was basically playing as the actorâ€™s personality and not as a character in the film. This really took me out of the movie because it didnâ€™t gel with the rest of the tone.Â 
3) A final third act that was really blown out of proportion. Many movies tend to do this for some weird reason, and I wish this one didnâ€™t.

Name: Fighter
Review: A solid military thriller across the board! Itâ€™s very easy to compare this unfavorably the Top Gun franchise, but I will not because it really is an unfair comparison. Those movies are essentially perfect, and there arenâ€™t other major aviator military films out there. Regardless, this film has a lot to commend.Â  There was a lot of great India nationalism vibes here (a.k.a â€œf*** yeah Indiaâ€) which was infectious. That made me really want to root for our protagonists through the whole film.Â  The film is very well paced too. It has a hefty runtime, but it didnâ€™t feel that way because there was always something engrossing going on.Â  I was also happy to see that the romance in the film did not feel forced. Forced romance is really common for action thrillers like this. But here, Deepika Padukoneâ€™s character brought forth many important parts to the story.Â  It was also refreshing to see Hrithik Roshan again on the big screen. This guy just naturally oozes charisma. He makes everyday song and dance numbers feel so much more hype. In a film where dance numbers should feel out of place, here I couldnâ€™t stop watching the dance numbers because he dances so well. The jokes around his charisma are definitely meta fan service, but alsoâ€¦he has charisma so it works.Â  I could nitpick the flaws present here. Yes, thereâ€™s a lot of telling and not showing. Yes, there are many conveniences. Yes, the over-the-top ludicrous action scenes donâ€™t mesh well with the realistic themes that the film brings up. But, the high moments are so high that I didnâ€™t care. This is a fun ride for anyone, even if you unfairly compare this to Top Gun.

Name: RoboCop
Review:
I feel refreshed with movies like this that were released many years ago but show a futuristic setting. Most movies nowadays will portray the future with a clean CGI feel. But movies back in the day will meticulously craft each detail and still keep a â€œdirtyâ€ setting to feel lived-in.Â 

My favorite parts of this film are the parts that feel the most realistic. This film shows an important issue with privatizing police work, which is thought-provoking. The POV perspectives from RoboCop (especially when he is first turned on) has the right type of realistic and creepy dark comedy. The emotions when RoboCopâ€™s face is shown for the first time is unsettling in the right ways.Â 

Huge respect for the actor of RoboCop that was able to act so well with just the mouth getting screen time for most of it.Â 

The over-the-top action scenes really didnâ€™t work for me. I was fully onboard with gore, but I was taken out of the film anytime unrealistic action scenes occurred. I think this choice was done to â€œfit inâ€ with 80s action flicks, but the premise really didnâ€™t need this.

Name: Animal
Review: This is without a doubt one of the worst films Iâ€™ve seen.Â  The best way to talk about this film is to compare it to Scarface. Scarface has a protagonist that has disgusting behaviors and commits evil acts to move up the criminal food chain. It also has over-the-top action and gore. The difference is that despite all these negativities, you as the viewer canâ€™t help but want to see the protagonist in ScarfaceÂ continue the evil acts and destroy everyone in his path. This is because he is very calculated in his actions, and in a way deserves his successes along the way.Â  On the other hand, this film does not have a compelling protagonist. In fact, he is unlikeable in every way. He is unhinged in an upsetting way, and not in a fearful way. Any normal person would clearly diagnose this person with a mental health problem, or be worthy of the death penalty with the crimes he commits. Yet, the film keeps pushing us root for this character (and even sympathize for him). The film and I were completely misaligned on this front.Â  I also couldnâ€™t appreciate the over-the-top action scenes. They werenâ€™t silly enough to laugh along, or smart enough to appreciate the art. I just wanted the action scenes to be over.Â  I have no idea how this film got so much box office love. Initially I felt proud that an Indian film was literally the number 1 film in the worldwide box office for a weekend. Now, I feel embarrassed that this film got such a distinction.

Name: Maestro
Review:
I wanted to like this movie because of how talented Bradley Cooper is. I am definitely still intrigued to see what more he can offer to film, but unfortunately I think this film really missed the mark.Â 

I admittedly knew nothing about Leonard Bernstein prior to this film. Hearing the music he conducted through the film really made me appreciate his talent, I didnâ€™t realize how prolific his music has been in the film industry. This excited me to learn about his creative planning. How does the brain of such a talented individual operate to generate the music we have the privilege of experiencing?
However, the film doesnâ€™t explore that. It felt more like a biography, with the composer bits as background filler.Â 
I also just couldnâ€™t buy into why this character succumbed to all his vices. It began with a very charming romantic relationship with his wife, and then he had a bunch of affairs. I get that these were the real events that occurred, but there wasnâ€™t enough to explain why he did that. Other biopics show how fame turns people into worse versions of themselves, but there wasnâ€™t enough here to show why he made all those choices.Â 

I guess there were good performances from Bradley Cooper and Carey Mulligan. But overall, there isnâ€™t enough memorable here for me. More focus on the music wouldâ€™ve made me feel more positive.

Name: Okja
Review: This has been in my Netflix watchlist for quite some time. The past Bong Joon-Ho films I watched were SnowpiercerÂ and Parasite, both of which I loved way more than I expected to. I knew I had to watch this soon because itâ€™s been on Netflix for a long time and I was afraid of it getting pulled off Netflix (still upset I didnâ€™t get the chance to see HushÂ before it got pulled off).Â  This film is definitely enjoyable. Lots of funny moments and many thrilling scenes. The chase sequences here are very top-notch, to the Spielberg level of quality. I have to give major points for a unique premise. And still huge respect to Bong Joon-Ho as a director. The main child actor of Ahn Seo-hyun was strong, and showcased a lot of admirable physical abilities for the role. The relationship between Mija and Okja was charming.Â  My problem with the film though, is that details felt very inconsistently executed. For example, the characters in the Animal Liberation Front strongly show that they will never harm animals or humans. But, there are moments when they do so when itâ€™s convenient for the plot. The character of Jake Gyllenhaal came off very annoying to me and out-of-place with the greater themes of the film.Â  Still, this is a good watch for all audiences. I think this is a pretty good first film to watch into the Bong Joon-Ho filmography.

Name: Bottoms
Review: With such a premise, I expected to roll my eyes and get frustrated with too much raunchiness and misguided directions. This ended up being solid laugh-out-loud silliness with a crowd. I definitely recommend watching this with an audience.Â  Iâ€™m glad that this didnâ€™t go over-the-top with preachiness, as many films nowadays do. This was a high school silly comedy that happens to have high school girls attracted to other girls. Thatâ€™s the right way to keep the audience invested. Jokes felt like they were crafted with proper comedic timing, and not as an assembly line of directives from executives.Â  I surprisingly really related to the main characters. Sure, they would say ridiculously stupid things, but what high school kid doesnâ€™t?Â  Marshawn Lynch as the advisor to the club was perfect in every way possible.Â  As for flaws, some parts went a little too ludicrous for me. Also, there were definite inconsistencies. Obviously this isnâ€™t a major negative for high school raunchy comedies, but it was enough to notice.Â  Years from now, I could definitely see this turning into cult status like Mean Girls.

Name: Lightyear
Review:
This is an absolutely thrilling space adventure that I wouldâ€™ve fallen in love with as a child. I totally believe that Andy wouldâ€™ve fallen in love with Buzz Lightyear from watching this film.Â 

The film went straight into thrills and it kept those thrills all the way until the end.Â 

I was very surprised with how thought-provoking this film turned into. It wasnâ€™t a run-of-the-mill average plot. There was a fascinating play with time travel that was emotionally effective. The protagonist was not just perfect from the start, and had required character growth to explore. The side characters were also very charming and relatable. I was afraid that they would be useless comic relief, but they had actual important impact to the plot.Â 

The setting isnâ€™t â€œflashyâ€ with bright colors, which I think was the right move because it felt more realistic. Although, this probably hurt its box office performance as kids and parents probably thought this would be boring.Â 

Without spoiling anything, the ultimate villain was actually perfect for our protagonist and didnâ€™t feel as cliched as I thought it would at first glance.Â 

My only flaw was that it couldâ€™ve gone less in the exposition (or at least convey the same exposition in a cleaner manner).

Name: Mystic River
Review: Personally I got into film a lot more from 2015 onwards - thatâ€™s when I started paying attention to specific actors and directors, and what gets the Oscar buzz. So Iâ€™m always surprised to learn about films that exist in the recent past that definitely wouldâ€™ve gotten my attention if I was my current age in that year. Here is one of those films - a Clint Eastwood directed film that one two Actor awards in the year when Lord of the Rings: The Return of the KingÂ swept everything.Â  I was super invested in this film at the very beginning. The opening scene with the kids was unsettling in the right ways. Then a jump to their adult selves - I couldnâ€™t wait to explore how the opening scene affected all of them.Â  What unfolded was a mystery that was definitely interesting and what makes me ultimately give this a positive review. Itâ€™s a solid mystery where we are given the right pieces of information at the right times, and feel the right doubts towards the right people as needed.Â  The ending unfortunately really tanked this movie for me. Without spoiling anything, it felt like the wrong characters were punished for the actions and the right characters were not punished for their actions. It almost felt like giant character shifts happened in the end out of the blue.Â  Apparently Sean Penn won an award here over Johnny Deppâ€™s Jack Sparrow. I strongly disagree with this. Sean Penn was good I guess, but it was a performance Iâ€™ve seen before. Jack Sparrow was most definitely lightning in a bottle that shouldâ€™ve been praised more than it did.

Name: The New Mutants
Review: While most people state that the MCU has cracked the ideal formula for a shared superhero universe (ignoring the quantity over quality in their recent projects), personally Iâ€™ve always appreciated the X-Men series a lot more. Sure, thereâ€™s been a wide range of quality in this series, but the great part about it is that there are many unique genres and aspects to it. We saw true grit with The Wolverine and Logan, we saw raunchy comedy gold with the Deadpool films, and we saw smart usage of time travel in Days of Future Past. And most underrated - we saw effective team up films with multiple superheroes without feeling exposition heavy.Â  The film adds to my appreciation of the X-Men series. It truly felt more like a horror film than what was attempted in Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness. It had believable and effective enough use of coming-of-age themes. Itâ€™s a contained film that sits well by itself, and is a believable addition to a superhero universe without feeling like a shameless set-up to other films. I wish franchises could branch out into other genres rather than sticking to the same formula - this is how franchises can branch out their audience appeal.Â  I was onboard with all the major choices in this film. The idea of five flawed teenage mutants (I almost ended that with â€œninja turtlesâ€ lol) in a confined space is fascinating. They are experiencing unusual life struggles during puberty stages - anyone would sympathize while watching this.Â  The contained nature was very refreshing - it genuinely didnâ€™t feel like a superhero film to me. There wasnâ€™t a bloated third act where the entire world would end unless *** happens. The ramifications were small scale but also investing to the characters.Â  Iâ€™m pretty upset that the story around this film was all around its delayed release time and potential reshoots and that itâ€™s from a now defunct franchise. There is a lot of merit in this film and it easily couldâ€™ve found a following amongst non-superhero fans too.Â  I do have some flaws.Â  I rarely say this, but it couldâ€™ve used more runtime to delve deeper into the backgrounds of the quirky characters. Understanding why they are how they are couldâ€™ve helped with relating to them better.Â  I was happy with the mix of horror with coming-of-age, but it couldâ€™ve gelled together more cleanly. It almost felt like Iâ€™d see different movies for each scene, when more effective editing wouldâ€™ve combined them together properly.Â  I wouldnâ€™t urge everyone to watch this, as itâ€™s not perfect. But I hope directions like this can be take for more franchise bloat we will inevitably see from Hollywood.

Name: Dune: Part Two
Review: In my Dune review, I gave myself an order to watch this film in IMAX. I actually held up to that, and Iâ€™m so glad I did. This is the first film in a while that I felt really needed the theater experience. In addition, I normally donâ€™t think IMAX is worth it, but here it was definitely warranted. The IMAX aspect ratio persisted through the whole film, truly elevating the scope of the visuals in this world.Â  The full budget of the film exists on the screen, and doesn't feel like they just funded high actor salaries. Denis Villeneuve is truly one of the greatest directors working today. He is able to effectively combine style with substance. Amongst all the films with an overabundance of CGI, the visuals in his film are masterfully crafted and stand out as beautiful spectacle.Â  This film has really weird moments like grasping water from corpses, a sentient fetus, and people riding sandstorms. A normal production would feel campy and stupid with all these elements. But, this film is able to incorporate these with a serious tone that is believable for the world crafted in front of our eyes. This is only possible from a truly talented director like Denis Villeneuve.Â  His signature direction is to take it slow to immerse you in the world he creates. While I do definitely appreciate this, it has a mixed effect on my love for his films. I loved it for Arrival, Prisoners, and Dune. I admittedly didnâ€™t love it in his other films. I think this film was a slightly slower pace than my liking.Â  I think the best way to praise this film is to compare it with John CarterÂ (which barely anyone saw or knows about). Both source materials influenced a lot of the sci-fi we know today. Both have been referred to as unadaptable to the film screen because it would ironically seem derivative to other sci-fi films that the mainstream audiences praise. Both had giant budgets with really weird world rules. John Carter absolutely tanked, while this one excels. Each character is perfectly cast and acted. Each character has fascinating unique traits that make them believably a part of the world. Javier Bardemâ€™s character generated a lot of great laughs for me (and his trait wasn't just comic relief but there was actual impact and reasoning behind this trait existing). Austin Butler went through a huge transformation from Elvis to one of the creepiest things Iâ€™ve ever seen. Through the runtime, I was really questioning the casting choice of TimothÃ©e Chalamet. I didnâ€™t really question it in DuneÂ because he didnâ€™t actually have too much focus time as a typical protagonist would. But in this film, he is much more of a central focus. Ultimately I think his casting choice made sense based on the plot developments near the end of the film. My interpretation is that this character is meant to have imperfections, and this performance made those plot choices believable.Â  Speaking of the plot, I was actually pretty surprised with the ending. I thought there would be huge scale third-act battles. The war battle scenes are breathtaking, but the characters took further focus. The characters had no easy decisions to make, and they all had the expected ramifications. Overall it didnâ€™t take any easy crowd-pleasing directions, but went much more thought-provoking routes.Â  My main flaw is that I think I needed more explanation for some of the lore in the film. I was surprised at how well I grasped all the required information in Dune without having any prior knowledge of the world. But here, a lot more lore was important to the plot and I didnâ€™t grasp every detail. Iâ€™m sure a rewatch with subtitles would solve the gaps for me, but for now this is how I feel.Â  In the future I will have to watch both films back-to-back as a marathon. I watched YouTube videos with a recap of the first film before watching this one, but there minor details from the first film that were significant callbacks in the second film. I will appreciate this more upon rewatch. Iâ€™m pretty surprised that audiences are reacting so positively to this film. Itâ€™s not an everyday blockbuster in that you can find enjoyment just in the visuals; it is paced slower than average, and you are required to listen closely to every word of dialogue to truly appreciate. In contrast, personally I think the Star WarsÂ and Lord of the RingsÂ films could get huge mass appeal because their fun visuals and fast paced nature could be attractive to all ages and backgrounds, even if their lores arenâ€™t perfectly understood. Maybe this is an indication that audiences will appreciate high brow entertainment more than I give them credit for. That is an overall good thing, so no complaints from me.

Name: Dunki
Review: A solid time pass with a unique premise! I was pretty hype about a collaboration between Shah Rukh Khan and Rajkumar Hirani. All of Hiraniâ€™s films have been classics. I love his comedic timing. However, I was personally mixed on SanjuÂ - I felt the purpose had a lot of inconsistencies and the comedy didnâ€™t really mesh well.Â  I was more positive with this film, but I have similar issues as with Sanju.Â  First, the premise. I think the main idea came across very well. The image of life in another country may appear all shiny and beautiful, but itâ€™s not as simple as that. I think this film did a great showcase of the complexities with immigration. Not every person needs to come into a country for safety - many times they have problems that wonâ€™t be solved by coming into another country. In that regard, I think this is a must-see for anyone that is thinking about immigrating. At the same time, we can relate to the suffering that people go through when they immigrate.Â  There were a good number of touching moments too. In particular, a court scene with Shah Rukh Khan had the right messaging (even if it wasnâ€™t directed perfectly).Â  Iâ€™ll also give some props to Shah Rukh Khan for actually being believable as a ~30 year old. Maybe it was a lot of really believable makeup? My main issue is the choice of incorporating Rajkumar Hiraniâ€™s comedic style into this premise. I donâ€™t think they meshed well together. This wouldâ€™ve been a much better film if it kept a serious tone about the immigration topic without incorporating slapstick comedy.

Name: Dawn of the Dead
Review: I am actually very shocked with how much I enjoyed this movie. It may be low brow zombie action without a greater purpose, but it executes it so well that I didnâ€™t care! I first heard about this movie in fourth grade when, for whatever reason, the entire class really wanted our teacher to play the movie for us. With the R-rating, that obviously was never going to happen. I joined the class and also championed for it, but that was solely because everyone else was doing it. Internally, nothing about zombies appealed to me at the time.Â  I decided to watch this because it was leaving Netflix soon. Also, Iâ€™m always most interested in seeing early films of well-known directors. Interestingly, some of my favorite films from directors are their early films when they utilized their limited budget to the fullest potential (e.g. Quentin Tarantinoâ€™s Reservoir Dogs, Christopher Nolanâ€™s Memento). Now, I have another example to add - Zack Snyder.Â  I expected mindless action, but I didnâ€™t actually get that. Thatâ€™s probably my favorite part of the film. All the action stayed consistent with the rules it presented, so despite a ludicrous zombie premise I could believe that this plot could actually exist in real life. Plans were clearly discussed and then executed, so you could understand why people made certain decisions. For example, a chainsaw plan was shown off before we actually see zombies killed by the chainsaw. Most movies wouldâ€™ve just shown the raw chainsaw killings for the cool visuals, but Zack Snyder smartly decided to include setup to keep believability.Â  Characters actually have scenes of experiencing emotional trauma, so they donâ€™t feel like lifeless creatures. We start the film with the protagonist losing her whole family. Later on, she runs away and is finally safe. As the adrenaline died down, we see a scene of her crying. Little moments like this are valuable to keep character consistency, and not feel like the film is only cutting back to characters when convenient for the plot.Â  I really liked the aspect where a greater number of zombies exist in the outside world as time goes on. This was the proper use of increasing escalating stakes as the film goes on, adding to the tension.Â  My one flaw was with everything around the pregnant character. That was the one moment where I felt characters acted very illogically and inconsistent with the rest of the film.Â  I was pleasantly surprised with the cast of this film, many cast members that were before projects I associate them with. All of them played different characters than what I was used to, and it was pleasant to see that range.Â  The protagonist of the film is acted by Sarah Polley, who would later direct Women Talking. Good for her! I didnâ€™t know that this movie was technically a remake until I subsequently read a couple reviews. Many of these reviews seemed to criticize the movie for not being a â€œproperâ€ adaptation because it removes the social commentary and focuses on raw zombie violence. Obviously I didnâ€™t watch the original movie, but I donâ€™t think I would share these thoughts. I would criticize in this way if it was an assembly line-produced film that just feels like everything else weâ€™ve seen. But, this is a zombie film that was still meticulously crafted, even if it was focused on the raw action aspects. Not everything needs valuable social commentary, as long as a solid journey is crafted.

Name: Being the Ricardos
Review: Aaron Sorkin is an absolute magician with screenplays, and that alone will always make me interested to see all of his work. The Social Network and Mollyâ€™s GameÂ are must-sees in my opinion due to his masterful screenplay. AndÂ this film also has that Aaron Sorkin signature grip.Â  This film has been on my watchlist for a while due to Aaron Sorkinâ€™s involvement. I do recall watching some I Love Lucy episodes had many laugh out loud moments, so I was curious to see Sorkinâ€™s take here.Â  From the first line, I was immediately pulled in. The Sorkin dialogue feels like its own character of the film that engrosses you into even the most boring subjects. It just snaps so fast, yet at the same time youâ€™re somehow able to keep track of everything. The film is able to mesh many subplots together without feeling like a lot to keep track of. This dialogue made me so invested into whatever this film was producing. It made even something as minor as table reads super thrilling. Whatever Aaron Sorkin has is an absolute superpower.Â  This dialogue was a great use of showcasing a unique part of the television creative production process that I found fascinating. As table reads and practices went through, the scripts of the episodes were scrutinized. Does it make sense for Lucy to make a certain action and say a certain line? Details like this matter to stay consistent with the character and keep the audience invested to watch the next episode. Being so detail-oriented was probably the reason that I Love Lucy was so successful.Â  My next favorite part of this film is definitely Nicole Kidman as Lucille Ball. I genuinely did not ever see Nicole Kidmanâ€™s face in this performance, because it truly felt like I was watching Lucille Ball. Her performance was also the sole reason that made me really want to research more about her backstory.Â  My criticism was around the second half of the film. It kinda felt like it lost the charisma that the first half had. I somehow became less interested and excited with how the plot was going to progress. This may be because the dialogue was not as gripping or the uniqueness lost its charm. Nothing was bad per se, but it felt like a drop in quality.

Name: Poor Things
Review: When I watch Oscar movies, it is common for me to think â€œI didnâ€™t hate it, but it felt so overhyped and undeserving of all those nominationsâ€. For this film, I have a unique feeling. It deserved all the Oscar wins (Emma Stone for Best Actress, Best Production Design, Best Costume Design, Best Makeup and Hairstyling) but itâ€™s really difficult for me to recommend anything else about it.Â  First with the positives. Yes, Emma Stone definitely deserved Best Actress. Acting as such a child with a messed up mental growth is not at all easy, and she performed it amazingly. I was in awe of everything she did.Â  Very unique feel. The Victorian London setting is usually very boring for me, but here it was combined with an oddly tinkered alternate universe and suddenly made it fascinating. Iâ€™d love to see another film with a completely different plot and characters in this setting.Â  The fisheye lens and off-putting score were perfect juxtaposition with the idea of this film. Given that the concept of creating a Frankenstein-like creature is so ethically wrong, having these off-putting editing choices adds to it. These were also done in a proper enough extent where I wasnâ€™t put off by the film itself.Â  My main issue is with the choice of going such a sexualized direction with the plot. That immediately just made me not interested in the plot. I donâ€™t know why many films choose this direction, and why it gets praised in awards regardless of the promiscuous themes. After logging this film in my Letterboxd, I noticed that most of my watched films of the year fell in the theme â€œerotic relationships and desireâ€ which is weird because itâ€™s the type of films I try to avoid. Looking at what encompassed this list, it was Saltburn, Call Me By Your Name, May December, Black Swan, and this film. Everything mentioned here are all Oscar buzz films. I think that definitely says something about the films that get awards attention (and therefore, why films keep exploring these themes).Â  I would normally just move on, but I feel a lot of shame from this film in particular. A film that is not rated R, didnâ€™t explore erotic themes, and kept this type of setting wouldâ€™ve had huge appreciation from everyday audiences. It definitely wouldâ€™ve gotten great word-of-mouth from everyone to experience it on the big screen. But because of its erotic themes, none of that will ever be experienced by most audiences.Â  I am interested enough with pieces of this film to check out more of the filmography or Yorgos Lanthimos. But, I canâ€™t recommend this film.Â  Sidebar - I saw a comment that mentioned Mark Ruffaloâ€™s character looks like Lalo Salamanca, and I seriously canâ€™t unsee that!

Name: Article 370
Review:
Seems like hereâ€™s another situation where critics rate this as very good or very bad, depending on their political leanings. I wish people could critique just the filmmaking of movies as separate from political themes.Â 
On the other hand, I understand that itâ€™s very difficult to portray relatively recent events in film without appearing subjective. History does need some time to fester to actually understand its ramifications. And thatâ€™s much harder for people to grasp in a world that has so much fast-paced social media atmosphere.Â 

Now, to the actual filmâ€¦

Admittedly, I donâ€™t have as much awareness of the politics with Kashmir. While this film explained aspects well enough, a stronger awareness of the Kashmir history definitely wouldâ€™ve helped here. But, this film did make me subsequently research about it so I do feel it is ultimately a good thing that it made me learn something to further my general knowledge.Â 

As far as the actual filmmaking, this is definitely competently made. A good mix of political thrills with action. Iâ€™m sure the actual events were not as cinematic as what the film shows, but to be honest every film about actual events is dramatized.Â 

My flaw is that parts did feel boring and dialogue did drag. Again, if I was more closely involved with Kashmir politics, Iâ€™d probably relate to it more and not feel as bored.Â 

Definitely a good watch. It will make you think about Kashmir politics in different ways, which is a good thing regardless of your personal political leaning. I never really felt like it was pushing propaganda.

Name: The Marvels
Review: Not the worst of the MCU, but very messy.Â  I admittedly had really low expectations going into this movie. The characterization of Captain Marvel has been subpar through the MCU, and I had low hopes of this getting better with this film. This was also a film that seemed to require a lot of homework across many tv shows.Â  The best praise I can give is that this movie didnâ€™t make me angry like the worst of the MCU (e.g. Ant-Man 3, She-Hulk). The worst of the MCU are ones that just shouldnâ€™t have existed in the first place. Here, I could actually see a good MCU addition with this idea. The problem was that it was executed as obligatory MCU content without having much purpose.Â  I agree with most criticisms that the screenplay was not crisp enough. Obviously no one expects perfection, but we expect at least something competent enough to follow along. Most plot points were explained away with quick science mumbo jumbo, without any setup/payoff.Â  There were fun moments that definitely warranted good laughs, but they just donâ€™t mesh well with the rest of the film. For example, Ms. Marvelâ€™s family were a part of fight scenes - this is funny, but itâ€™s unbelievable for a family like that to fight alien soldiers. Superheroes begging for help on a planet feels like low stakes when everyone on the planet sings. Iâ€™m not against these choices in a film, but they donâ€™t work juxtaposed with everything else.Â  There were parts of this that felt like a great and unique addition to the franchise. The best parts were when the three leads were just being girls together (e.g. everyone comforting each other, practicing alignment with body switching). If this was explored more, I predict the film wouldâ€™ve been a lot more praised and been a lot more positive with the box office.Â  I agree that Iman Vellaniâ€™s Ms. Marvel was the best part of this film, but Iâ€™d rather recommend watching her own show than this film. A side praise is that you didnâ€™t actually need to see other properties in the franchise to fully appreciate this film.Â  I feel the most bad for Brie Larson. She was great in Room and undoubtedly has great acting talent. The MCU just isnâ€™t exploring her talent well enough, and Iâ€™m worried that the MCU is preventing her from getting valuable other projects to grow through.

Name: Anatomy of a Fall
Review: Many days after watching this film, Iâ€™m still thinking hard about all the scenes Iâ€™ve watched.Â  I went into this film expecting a mystery type of movie on how a murder occurred. What I did not expect was the thought-provoking social commentary. I somehow ended the film caring less about the murder mystery aspect (which was still fascinating) and more about the themes of truths to each individual. I found myself making many comparisons to real-life highly publicized court cases.Â  This is my favorite type of social commentary from films. Many films (e.g. Donâ€™t Look Up) are so direct on forcing you to learn its messages and agree with them, and I think as a result they become less effective. On the other hand, smarter films like this will lay out the premise and leave the interpretation to the viewer.Â  As a viewer, I was gripped into the courtroom scenes because I also felt like I was trying to solve the mystery. As I heard a recording of a verbal argument between a husband and wife, I too was asking â€œIs there any evidence of motive within this conversation, or is it totally unrelated?â€Â  The film was properly edited in every regard. Details around the murder and family members were revealed at the right parts of the film to keep me invested. Cuts between us actually seeing the verbal argument, and the courtroomâ€™s reactions to the transcript were executed perfectly. The mix of spoken languages was unique to see in a film, yet also realistic since many people are exposed to multiple languages in day-to-day life.Â  Here are one of the few examples where I believe a film actually deserved its Oscar attention. My only addition is that the child performance was stellar - I havenâ€™t seen enough reviews mention this.Â  My one criticism is that I felt the filmâ€™s runtime. It couldâ€™ve been about 30 minutes shorter.Â  It is a movie focused on dialogue. Donâ€™t let that deter you from watching it, but donâ€™t watch it when youâ€™re getting tired.

Name: Notting Hill
Review:
Classic rom-com with great fun and charm!

Iâ€™m always down for a charming rom-com, itâ€™s a great mood-booster. I was intrigued by this film because itâ€™s one of many that launched Julia Roberts into a household name for rom-coms. 

My favorite part is that this feels like a time capsule to simpler times. Things arenâ€™t overly flashy and sexualized. Despite Julia Roberts actually having an actress role in the movie, she came off as less â€œfakeâ€ than what I see in modern rom-coms. This probably has a lot to do with social media. 
In addition, despite this film being known more for Julia Roberts than Hugh Grant, we donâ€™t really see much about the background of her character. While normally this would feel odd, here it worked because it added to the â€œmysteriousnessâ€ of an actress meshing in normal world.Â 

Another thing I really appreciated is that the comedic lines were written in a much more natural manner. We still had eccentric characters, but the jokes still felt like they fit in, rather than stopping the whole rhythm of the scene for a punchline. 

There was a point near the end of the film where I was shocked it was gonna go in an unconventional direction, but I was a bit disappointed that it ended in the normal. This isnâ€™t necessarily bad, just something I noticed.Â 

Overall this is a fun time pass if you want a rom-com mood booster. I could understand it being a hit at the time of release, but I donâ€™t see a major reason to seek this one out.

Name: Wonka
Review: Itâ€™s impossible to watch this film without smiling :D Like everyone else, I also had low expectations for some reason going into this. I wasnâ€™t convinced with Timothee Chalamet being a proper Willy Wonka, an origin story of Willy Wonka felt like a cash grab, and the trailers didnâ€™t really pull me in.Â  Also like everyone else, I was very charmed and donâ€™t know why I went in with low expectations. Iâ€™m admittedly not in love with PaddingtonÂ and Paddington 2Â but I agree that those are very cute movies and I wish more family-friendly films could match that charm. Paul King definitely brings that classic charm to this film too. From the second I saw the opening credits mention â€œA Paul King confectionâ€, I knew Iâ€™d be watching a film that is truly embracing its charm.Â  This is the type of movie that I wish could be made more often. Iâ€™m the biggest defender of everyday animated films because they are entertaining and visually beautiful, but I do understand that adults can feel bored by the conventional ones. This type of film is what would be appreciated even by such adults. Thereâ€™s lots of silly humor that is clean for kids and also fun for adults.Â  What surprised me the most is that despite being a prequel to a known IP, it really feels unique. The setting feels like its own character with a lot to explore. Willy Wonkaâ€™s whim was super fun in a lead role of a film. It had a lot of silliness without losing credibility. No distracting romantic subplot with the main character.Â  I was initially very skeptical with Timothee Chalamet as the choice. I didnâ€™t really feel much charm from the trailers for some reason. The film itself shows him with lots of positivity and whim that is infectious to the viewers. He may not match the depictions of prior film adaptations, but that doesnâ€™t matter because he brings his own fun personality into it. With this film and Dune: Part Two, I will now officially stop doubting Timothee Chalamet.Â  It was released at the perfect time in theaters. This is a perfect Christmas time movie theater trip. Kids and adults all will walk away with joy. I could definitely imagine this becoming a cult classic for kids growing up around the release of this movie. Making it as a musical was actually a great choice. I donâ€™t really imagine the songs becoming memorable through the years, but they are fun musical numbers to watch and fit in well with the plot.Â  The only thing that stops me from a perfect score is the love story subplot with Olivia Colemanâ€™s character. That was too weird for me, and I didnâ€™t enjoy how many times the film cuts back to this.Â  Another weird nitpick I have is that I didnâ€™t really walk away from this film with a craving for chocolate. Not that a film like this was required to do so, but I definitely walked away from the other film adaptations with a chocolate craving.Â  Overall, this is a great mood-boosting watch for all types of audiences.

Name: House of Gucci
Review: Well filmed, but also unfortunately forgettable.Â  Ridley Scott as director is enough for me to watch a film. Admittedly, that was the only draw for me.Â  Credit where credit is due - great performances across the board. Lady Gaga in particular was stellar. I wouldnâ€™t call her Oscar worthy, but she stood out amongst other huge and refined actors like Al Pacino.Â  Jared Leto actually didnâ€™t annoy me as much as other reviews state. I honestly could not see his face under those prosthetics - reminded me of Colin Farrell in The Batman.Â  Once the film shows what itâ€™s truly about, it gets a lot more interesting. The yearn for power was intriguing, but not to levels comparable to Game of Thrones or Breaking Bad. You canâ€™t help but respect how well Patrizia Reggiani operates (even if sheâ€™s a criminal).Â  The most interesting portions to me were when it was focused on how to improve the Gucci brand (e.g. Lady Gagaâ€™s character seeking out the off-brand products).Â  The main drawback for me was that it overall felt derivative of other historical business stories. More emphasis on the Gucci empire and products wouldâ€™ve interested me.Â  Also, the film is definitely 30 minutes longer than it needed to be.Â  The only reason Iâ€™d recommend watching is to complete Ridley Scottâ€™s filmography (or if you love the Gucci story).

Name: Creed III
Review: Another thrilling boxing story in a consistent franchise. Iâ€™ve given every film in this franchise a positive review, and it continues with this film.Â  There was apparently a lot of behind-the-scenes drama with Sylvester Stallone not being involved in this film. I donâ€™t have enough backstory to comment on the business dealings there. But what I can say is I didnâ€™t think this film felt â€œincompleteâ€ with the exclusion of Rockyâ€™s character. Rocky had a pretty good sendoff in Creed II, so I think the franchise is set up fine to only focus on Adonis Creed going forward.Â  This film included anime-style editing through its boxing scenes. This actually worked for me very well. Most live-action anime adaptations fail because they canâ€™t keep the same tone that was possible with the anime. But here, I felt it was well done. I felt like I could vision the thought process that the boxers went through right before they made their punches.Â  The downside of this editing choice is that it doesnâ€™t feel as much like real fighting occurring on screen. My personal favorites of the franchise are the fights that feel the most real. That being said, I welcome changes that are done well like this.Â  Totally loved the performances of Michael B. Jordan and Jonathan Majors. Damian was a great foil to Adonis and I was fully bought into this storyline. I definitely felt this â€œvillainâ€ character is amongst the best realized of the franchise because it had moments of affecting not just Adonis but others in his family. A particular conversation between Damian and Bianca about fame was very intriguing for me.Â  The whole film was well paced, which kept it from being boring.Â  The main flaw I had with this film was the editing of the storylines. Plot points ended in odd ways. In particular, a plot point about Amara (Adonis and Biancaâ€™s daughter) initially developed in an interesting manner because the parents had very opposite ways to address it and I was curious to see how it would resolve. But, this plot point ended up not being really resolved.Â  Slight nitpick - this film plot depends on Adonis and Damian being â€œoldâ€ and â€œpast their primesâ€.
