This was pretty hard to believe, considering how ripped their bodies clearly are through the film. In contrast, Sylvester Stallone was 60 years old when Rocky BalboaÂ released and it was much easier to buy into an aging athlete there. It wouldâ€™ve made much better sense to choose a story with these characters that fit their ages. In addition, with a story like this, Iâ€™m skeptical on what could be believable stories in sequels.

Name: Blue Beetle
Review: The most â€œSuperhero: The Movieâ€ superhero movie Iâ€™ve seen.Â  I had fairly high hopes going into this. Of the 4 DCEU movies released in 2023, this one seemed to have the best reviews. And I personally felt positive about Shazam: Fury of the Gods and The Flash, so I thought Iâ€™d be positive about this one too.Â  In addition, I absolutely loved Xolo MaridueÃ±a in Cobra KaiÂ and thought heâ€™d be a fantastic choice for a young superhero. I was also looking forward to seeing George Lopez again for the first time in a while.Â  Unfortunately, everything about this movie reeked of clichÃ©s. A random person suddenly gets superpowers and has a scene of struggling to utilize the superpowers. Then, we just believe that he suddenly has full control of his powers, which leads to a CGI fest of fight scenes. A shoehorned romantic subplot. A one-note corporate villain focused just on evil, complete with a whole mansion on an island.Â  What seemed so odd to me was this film had all the pieces to be much more. There are glimpses of an urban city where skyscrapers had holograms, juxtaposed with the area our lead family lives that is struggling to pay rent for a puny house. I thought this would have a unique perspective to the overdone theme of rich getting richer and poor getting poorer. But, these hologram buildings are literally just showpieces in the background. Our corporate villainâ€™s building doesnâ€™t even have the hologram aesthetic that the neighboring buildings have, which is odd especially when this corporation is touted as hugely corrupt and rich.Â  What I found refreshing about these characters was that it was a young adult with superpowers that wasnâ€™t hiding his powers from his family. Many times we donâ€™t see relatives involved with the superhero (and this was a family with investing characterization) so I was excited to see their involvement. But, we donâ€™t get enough time to flesh this out. The formulaic plot requirements of getting characters into certain places at certain times really hindered the potential here.Â  George Lopez didnâ€™t really work for me here either. It seems his characterization was basically giving plot armor to our heros, and I didnâ€™t think his comedic lines were that good.Â  Xolo as Jaime Reyes/Blue Beetle was great casting, and this couldâ€™ve flourished a lot more if the movie was better for him.Â  A characterization mentioned is that Jaime Reyes is completely against murder (even to villains). This was set up for one interesting plot point in the end, but other than that this was basically forgotten by the film. His relatives literally killed many people. Jaime was in scenes where others died and he couldâ€™ve saved them if he truly cared about this mindset.Â  Grandma with a Gatling gun is definitely a fun watch, and I wouldâ€™ve been much more on board if the film set this up better.Â  The worst for me were the plot conveniences that weâ€™re somehow supposed to ignore. In a world where the villain has an unlimited supply of technology and army men, itâ€™s hard to believe that an everyday family is able to escape their wrath. Jaime goes through many scenes where heâ€™s scared with his new superpowers, but then is having a blast when fighting baddies - almost like the movie wants to have grit and fun action at the same time but doesnâ€™t do the effort to edit these things well.Â  Iâ€™d probably be a lot less harsh on the movie if Iâ€™ve seen less than 5 superhero movies before and arenâ€™t caught on with the clichÃ©s. But after seeing so many, I canâ€™t take another one that just plays it safe and goes through all the conventions.

Name: Kindergarten Cop
Review:
Iâ€™ll give it props for this - most accurately named movie title ever. A kindergarten teacher that is actually an undercover cop.Â 

This is a really odd comedy. On one side, the concept of an undercover cop as a kindergarten teacher just yells elementary/family comedy. On the other hand, thereâ€™s many adult references here to give it a PG-13 rating. The fact that this was actually profitable in its box office run goes to show the star power of Arnold Schwarzenegger at his peak. I highly doubt this film could be made today.Â 

There were moments that I really appreciated and wished had more focus in the film. For example, Schwarzeneggerâ€™s brute anger towards a father that beats his child. Also, his policing disciplines implemented on kindergarteners. I wish the focus went more on these moments than the unnecessary crude humor.Â 
I would love to have another version of this movie with no crude humor so that it can actually be accessible to children.Â 

I also admittedly wasnâ€™t that invested into the criminal aspect of the film.Â 

The ending involved a shooting in a school. Yup, that definitely wouldnâ€™t be included in a comedy today.

Name: Moulin Rouge!
Review:
I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve been so conflicted on a movie review as much as this one.Â 

It has lots of elements that I thoroughly enjoy with a film. Catchy musical covers and wacky comedic elements always give me a smile. The setting is very unique and I couldnâ€™t help but be charmed by it. Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman undoubtedly have chemistry together and were the right choices for their roles. I will likely rewatch many musical elements on YouTube for years to come, especially â€œThe Pitchâ€.Â 

Overall, I left the film feeling incomplete. I didnâ€™t really understand the point of the whole film. Was it just supposed to be fun pizzazz, or is there a greater message here? I seem to feel this way with all Baz Luhrmann films Iâ€™ve watched so far - I am charmed, but the editing choices feel too random for me and prevented me from being invested in the story. On the other hand, I personally connect well with Wes Andersonâ€™s wackiness because it feels better executed and in line with the story.Â 

Ultimately, I canâ€™t help but respect this film for its uniqueness. I didnâ€™t connect with many choices, but it was very risky to create. It is all somehow a beautiful chaos and I did enjoy sitting through it.

Name: Dumb and Dumber
Review:
A consistent piece of joy from start to finish!

What worked very well here was the characterization of Harry and Lloyd. They really perfected the level of immaturity. They didnâ€™t just act like six year olds or like bratty teenagers - they utilized certain silly qualities in perfectly matched scenarios. It almost felt like what the best improv scenes entail - find the gift, and capitalize all the humor around that gift.Â 
The inconsistency in behaviors, while normally would be a negative, were perfect here because it made their reactions that much more unpredictable and funny.Â 
I think the reason this worked so well for me was that the characterizations were juxtaposed with a criminal plot. There were criminals thinking that Harry and Lloyd were really smart crooks, and knowing that they really arenâ€™t is hilarious.Â 

The look and feel of the film was charming too. Opening credits with incorrect spelling are little moments that set up the tone well.Â 

This film made me respect Jim Carrey more. Most of the films Iâ€™ve seen of his were â€œpast his primeâ€. Seeing him during his prime timeframe made me really understand what people saw in him and how he got so many film opportunities and box office success.Â 

I do miss comedy films like this. Comedy films today seem to be overly raunchy and flashy, while at the same time trying to hold back to avoid getting canceled. I personally felt that this film is still very watchable today.Â 

My only criticisms are that some jokes went too disgusting and I wasnâ€™t a fan of the romance subplot.

Name: American Fiction
Review:
This film is very refreshing for its concept, and Iâ€™m glad it got awards buzz (even if I feel like there are other more deserving films).Â 

Everything about the main storyline with Monkâ€™s career worked for me. The sarcastic comedic timing of Jeffrey Wright was unlike anything else Iâ€™ve seen. It was super funny to see his joke unbelievably grow out of control. I totally understood his frustration of getting pigeonholed into certain writing tropes based on the color of his skin. I think this brings forth a very fascinating conversation point for viewers of the film.Â 

This is the type of adult comedy I want to see more of. Most adult comedy these days is either overly raunchy or super political. The comedy here felt much more relaxing.Â 

Without spoiling anything, I thought the ending of the film was very smart, and Iâ€™m kinda surprised I havenâ€™t seen this style of an ending in other films.Â 

What didnâ€™t work for me as much was the storyline with Monkâ€™s family and his relationship. Any time it cut to this really felt like a completely different movie, and I didnâ€™t understand its inclusion. I enjoyed the character played by Traci Ellis Ross, but we donâ€™t get much of her in the film.Â 
I also seriously didnâ€™t like Sterling K. Brownâ€™s character in the film. His characterization and actions just felt too unbelievable to me in the context of the rest of the family. The inclusion of this character almost felt like it had to fall into an Oscar bait trope for the film to be accepted, which to me felt like the opposite message that the main storyline was trying to convey.Â 

Overall this film boasts a unique humor and poses interesting questions. I didnâ€™t think certain subplots connected well, but I can let that slide. Very curious to see more from Cord Jefferson.

Name: Rush
Review: A surprisingly enjoyable thrill ride in the world of race car driving.Â  I was admittedly not the most stoked into watching this film. I already saw very good race car movies that were based on true stories (Ford v FerrariÂ and Gran Turismo) so I was skeptical on if another film within this niche would really appeal to me. I decided to watch it because it was leaving Netflix soon, and my recent Hans Zimmer soundtrack listens kept bringing up music from this film.Â  At the beginning I was admittedly not that interested. The leads were presented with cocky and toxic masculinity. On one side this presented some fun (albeit fake) trash reality television, but on the other hand I just didnâ€™t think I would relate to their hurdles.Â  As I was solidifying this thought, a certain accident occurred in the film. After this point, the film became much more interesting to me. It gave thrills through the rest of the runtime, and it provided strong depth to our lead characters. It was a relationship I didnâ€™t expect to care about, and then suddenly did.Â  The racing scenes were all filmed in a great thrilling manner. They did a good job of showing how dangerous the sport is, which increased the adrenaline rush. After this film ended, I was interested enough to look up more about the real events and the lives of James Hunt and Niki Lauda. (Sidebar - I still find it hilarious that I never care for professional sports until I experienced a dramatized version of it on film). There were definitely creative liberties taken which deviated from the actual events. Normally this turns me off, because usually the actual events are more interesting to me than what we actually see. But in this case, I agreed with the creative liberties as it strengthened the relationship between our leads. Iâ€™m also at peace knowing that the real Niki Lauda approved of the film.Â  I wish the film steered away from scenes with nudity. I understand this was included to emphasize the masculine nature of James Hunt, but I think that was effective already through the other ways the film presented. The nudity served no purpose other than preventing families from enjoying this film together.Â  A nitpick I had was I wish the film showed a bit more about the technique behind the drivers. Itâ€™s not a major deal to me though, because the focus of the film is with the relationship between the two leads.

Name: Civil War
Review: Arguably one of the best movie concepts and executions Iâ€™ve ever seen.Â  The concept of a modern day civil war in the US just screams divisiveness. I know that if the direction chosen was one with heavy political commentary, it would be lauded by half the population and criticized by the other half and none of the reviews would appropriately review the filmmaking. So I fully agree with the decision to avoid any political commentary here, and simply focus on the effects of what would happen if a civil war took place today. The decision to not reveal the motivations of the factions smartly worked here, because I think any viewer would universally assume that the situation couldâ€™ve been preventable, and itâ€™s sad to see that the situation came to this.Â  The best part is the direction of the violence. There are a plethora of superhero, action, and military films out there. But, this is one of the few that truly made me feel chilling and uncomfortable (the only main one I can think of that felt similar was the opening of Saving Private Ryan). I think this was partly because the violence scenes were not cinematic or glamorized. They were real gunshot sounds, and real injuries.Â  But, I think the main reason I felt this way while watching was the fact that this was a civil war in America. Itâ€™s clear that these people were normal citizens that later became cutthroat individuals ready to snipe their neighbors. While the film never explains why they do what they do, you understand that they have to act this way or they will be killed by the enemy faction.Â  Another choice I appreciated was filming this from the perspective of neutral journalists. In a way, this might have been the most unbelievable part of the film because journalism is obviously far from neutral today. The journalists in this film werenâ€™t just neutral by name, but they literally donâ€™t intervene with killings that occur so that they can portray the real story. It was really fascinating to see that juxtaposition.Â  Great to see Kirsten Dunst again in a film. I really need to check out more of her filmography. The best parts of the film were with Jesse Plemons. I wish the marketing didnâ€™t focus so much on this actorâ€™s existence so that it couldâ€™ve added that much more effect upon watching the film.Â  What didnâ€™t really work for me was the filmâ€™s ending with our main characters. Choices felt out of left field and abrupt. It seemed like the film was trying to make a statement with these choices. If that is the case, that almost feels like the film betrayed the choice from the earlier parts of the film to avoid political commentary.Â  Overall, a thrilling yet chilling film that I recommend all to watch.

Name: The Holdovers
Review: A Christmas film that has a lot of charm despite no flash.Â  I really appreciate that this film was not only set in the 1970s, but was filmed as if it was released in the 1970s. Historical films these days still have a glossy sheen on it that doesnâ€™t feel genuine, but I didnâ€™t feel that way here.Â  When the film began with five boys staying in boarding school through the break, I expected this to be the type of film where kids of all cliques start to actually learn appreciative things about each other. While I have nothing against that type of film, we have seen a lot of those before. Once I learned it was more about just one boy and the relationship with other school staff, it went into unexpectedly charming directions. This teacher-student dynamic felt much more realistic than what we see in typical coming-of-age films. Little moments such as the DIY dessert from Paul and Mary to Angus gave me warm fuzzies.Â  I appreciated how the characterization of Paul Giamattiâ€™s character was kept consistent through the film. He has the same odd way with words and â€œunattractivenessâ€, but as you continue watching you grow to appreciate him as Angus does.Â  As much as I enjoyed watching this, I donâ€™t really see this film becoming a household rewatch tradition like Home Alone or Planes, Trains, and Automobiles. While the cursing in the film is realistic and not over-the-top, itâ€™s enough to prevent children from watching it. While less flash is a nice breath of fresh air, the flip side of the coin is that it wonâ€™t have big meme-able moments to be memorable. I see this less as a must-watch and more of a solid time-pass.

Name: Napoleon
Review:
Any film I see of Ridley Scott will only make me more appreciative of his craft. He brings huge variety and quantity to the big screen, even at post-retirement age. A film like this seems like it can only be made with a high energy middle-aged director, so the fact that such an old person can still construct a huge historical war drama is nothing short of commendable.Â 

The production design of this film is tremendous. I genuinely felt like I was in the time period of this film, from the visual effects to costume design. An early scene involving a horse with a cannonball set me up for the brutal vibes I was about to endure. All battle sequences in the show were chillingly scary in a good way. Even if I didnâ€™t follow along with story details, the visuals were entertaining enough through the runtime.Â 
Admittedly, all of this was also a good distraction to the fact that all the French people arenâ€™t even talking French. This linguistic choice didnâ€™t even take me out of the movie because the strong set design pulled me in.Â 

The odd choice here was that despite being a film with meticulously crafted detail to the time period and huge war battle set pieces, the main portion of this film is Napoleonâ€™s toxic relationship with Josephine. I wanted to appreciate this choice for being against-type (and potentially being a unique way to understand Napoleonâ€™s leadership motivations), but couldnâ€™t get there. These moments felt more like unnecessary drama than juicy drama. I kept wanting to go back to the huge battle sequences.Â 

It seems many criticized the historical inaccuracies. Admittedly I donâ€™t know this history closely enough to comment on that. Either way, I donâ€™t think itâ€™s as important of a negative compared to the choice to focus on the toxic relationship.Â 

The visuals alone are enough to feel entertained through the runtime, but donâ€™t expect anything more.

Name: Pinocchio
Review:
One of the few pieces of film that is actually timeless.Â 

Usually when I watch old films, I have to subconsciously add a buffer in interest. Live-action films would be in black-and-white, slow-paced, and visually not as captivating as todayâ€™s films. For this reason, I tend to stay away from films older than the 1980s.Â 
However, I donâ€™t say the same for this film. In fact, a part of me wishes that animated films could go back to this style and simplicity. I was surprised by how captivated I was by the entertainment value, despite it being over 80 years old.Â 

My favorite part about this film is its simplicity. Todayâ€™s animated films are a much grander scale, with top-notch visuals and many characters and thorough world-building. On the other hand, this film is actually very contained. There really arenâ€™t that many characters here. We arenâ€™t even really shown much about the world itself. It is assumed that most of the world (besides the portions we see) mimic human life closely, so the film doesnâ€™t waste time to show any of that. Instead, the film focuses on Pinocchioâ€™s journey. In a way, this simplistic choice also worked because we traverse the world through Pinocchioâ€™s lack of awareness.Â 

Given that Pinocchio is a household name known for his giant nose that gets bigger when he lies, I thought this would be utilized much more than what the film actually does. It was actually a bigger story about growing up in the right direction. The message is not only great but also an important universal message, which I why I believe the film is so timeless.Â 
But more than the appreciation of the message, above all else the film was an entertaining watch. The film here had a structure of an entertaining animated watch, which happened to have a good message. Animated films these days seem to have the opposite structure: determine the message, and form a film around that. I believe that is actually a negative because it has lead to lower quality entertainment and wouldnâ€™t be as timeless anymore.Â 

This film made me feel super nostalgic about the old Tom and Jerry cartoons I used to watch. Despite the animation being old, it was still very entertaining. Iâ€™m now energized to explore more animations of the past.Â 

This isnâ€™t a perfect film by any means. I think parts could have been edited better. But itâ€™s still a worthy watch for all.

Name: Cowboys & Aliens
Review: A colossal misfire of a promising premise.Â  This film seemed to have all the pieces needed for a huge box office hit. The literal James Bond and Indiana Jones together, directed by Jon Favreau (whose filmography I think has a wide variety of solid hits) with a giant budget and a western sci-fi premise. Not only does it have the resources, but it had a unique premise not really seen before. I wouldâ€™ve expected everything about this to be awesome.Â  I knew this was a box office bomb, but given all the pieces I was really hoping I could be on the side of the film. Unfortunately, it is difficult to defend.Â  Everything about this just felt so generic. A few days later, I forgot many details about this film. I remembered a lot more about a 1940s Disney film and a Wes Anderson short.Â  The set pieces felt normal. I didnâ€™t feel like I was a part of the western world, which I expect with the amount of talent and budget here.Â  The aliens also felt very generic too. Visually they were very normal. I wish we could get more fascinating details about the aliens, or get much less information about them to get a mysterious dread.Â  The action wasnâ€™t interesting enough for me to be thrilled with either.Â  Something that also really didnâ€™t fit in here was the use of amnesia in Daniel Craigâ€™s character. Amnesia is such an overused plot device, and it didnâ€™t really help here. He seemed to randomly remember convenient pieces of information and convenient plot moments. It didnâ€™t add any intriguing mystery (such as in The Bourne Identity), it just added frustration.Â  This isnâ€™t a â€œbadâ€ film in the grand scheme of things. It doesnâ€™t do anything terrible. I could understand people viewing this as a mindless thrill. But I really needed a lot more to recommend it.

Name: The Wonderful Story of Henry Sugar
Review:
Classic Wes Anderson!

This easily wouldâ€™ve been a pretty good film if it was a faithfully adapted Roald Dahl film, with some details stretched to a feature length. But, Wes Anderson of course incorporated his whim into it, to make it a super fun journey. The fact that basically the whole film was a live narration is genius and showcases the talent of Wes Anderson.Â 

I will show this to whoever needs an entrance into the world of Wes Anderson. Bonus points for the fact that itâ€™s a short, so much easier to invest time into.Â 

Because it is a short, we donâ€™t really get to explore as much as of the whimsical world or plot with this. Thatâ€™s my only complaint. Maybe Iâ€™ll feel less critical if I explore his other Roald Dahl adaptations.

Name: The Sting
Review: I havenâ€™t heard of this film until Netflix randomly brought this film to the front of my screen. I decided to watch this film because it was leaving Netflix soon and it was apparently a Best Picture winner. I went into it expecting to feel like â€œhomeworkâ€ just to complete the Best Picture winners. I ended up thoroughly enjoying this.Â  This is a type of film that probably would never win Best Picture today. It doesnâ€™t showcase innovative filmmaking or a greater message. It is simply a thrill ride amongst scammers trying to scam a mob boss. It has appeal to everyday audiences, not just the cinephiles. Love the throwback story time feel this had, from the title cards to the ragtime music (especially The Entertainer).Â  We first see our main character of Johnny Hooker as an obvious scammer. Itâ€™s pretty difficult to have the audience side with a person that committed a crime. But, seeing the deeper criminal underworld and exploring characterizations of Johnny Hooker and his counterparts made me want him to succeed.Â  There was a twist reveal in the third act that I truly didnâ€™t see coming. Â  I thoroughly adored the poker shots in the film. It reminded me heavily of Casino Royale. Now I want to watch more poker shots in films.Â  It was interesting to watch a film from the 1970s being a throwback film to the 1930s. I feel a like a film today that was set in the 1930s would have a much cleaner feel than the scrappy, lived-in world we see here.Â  I donâ€™t really view this as a must-see. It had fun thrills, but none that other films havenâ€™t done with more to offer.

Name: The Notebook
Review: A pretty solid romantic film with enough uniqueness to stand out, despite its narrative flaws.Â  I was bought in through the first third of the film. While Noahâ€™s first interaction seemed odd for me, I quickly bought into the chemistry between Noah and Allie. I understood the charm they had for each other, and why their social class differences caused the arguments they had. While I normally disapprove of sex scenes in films (and I also disapprove of the sex scenes in this film), this first one was filmed in a nervous and realistic manner which I appreciated. The beginning overall had the typical charms of a rom-com, while also bringing enough uniqueness with the setting and various creative choices.Â  We get enough characterization from Allie to understand her dilemma between choosing two life partners. That is definitely key accept the confusions and arguments that occur.Â  The film did a good job of depicting a 1940s romance for modern audiences. This brought some charm and refreshing nature to film.Â  Although, a nitpick is that I didnâ€™t think the 1940s were depicted super accurately. It doesnâ€™t take away any of the impact of the film, but it was particular front of mind for me after watching The Sting.Â  Once certain events cause the leads to become physically distant, I started rolling my eyes at choices that didnâ€™t make much sense. For example, Allieâ€™s mother goes strongly out of her way to prevent communication from Noah. But, this decision doesnâ€™t really make sense when we later on learn something about Allieâ€™s motherâ€™s past. It seemed like these occurred as plot conveniences, rather than consistent reasoning.Â  No, I donâ€™t expect perfect logic in a rom-com (or any genre for that matter). But, this was a huge complication within the plot so I wouldâ€™ve expected it to be more thought out.Â  Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™m in the minority here. Iâ€™m someone that really hates the plot of Romeo and Juliet, even though mainstream people consider this to be the best love story every created.Â  Overall, definitely worth a watch.

Name: Ante... Sundaraniki!
Review:
A typical time-pass Telugu rom-com. Not a must-see, but itâ€™s a fun time.Â 

I strongly appreciated that there was no unnecessary action subplots because it totally wasnâ€™t required for this plot.Â 

Funny one-liners and twists and turns made the journey of the film fun.Â 

The themes explored with an interfaith couple were done mostly realistically.Â 

I wouldâ€™ve preferred much less â€œjokesâ€ around the infertility content.

Name: The Zone of Interest
Review:
A lot to appreciate here.Â 

This is a great example of a film that has awards buzz and is not a hugely budgeted film, but still one worth seeing on the big screen. 

Very well deserving of the Oscar for best sound. The film essentially takes place during the Holocaust from the perspective of a Nazi family. They live normal lives, but you occasionally hear Holocaust-related sounds in the background (and Holocaust-related minor visuals details).Â 
Sound was smartly utilized as a completely separate tone from what we are directly viewing on screen. Being a slight background sound was somehow more creepy than actually seeing what was happening in the background.Â 

Itâ€™s even more creepy when you see how tone-deaf the main characters are to the people suffering in the background. Our main characters were focusing on improving their garden and getting new lipstick from victims, while the victims in the background are basically getting murdered. Absolutely vile.Â 

This film feels less as a film and more as an experience. It reminded me of a time I was at the Civil Rights Museum in Atlanta: there was a simulation where you had to sit in a diner while hearing racial slurs typically heard in the 1950s. I did not last long there. But Iâ€™m glad that I went through that simulation to have some understanding of the tragedies of life in that time period.Â 

While I agree the experience in this film is important for all to go through, I donâ€™t see it much more than an experience. A feature-length runtime was utilized with a plot that didnâ€™t seem like it had importance to share, compared to the experience. I think this just needed to be a short film consisting of vignettes.Â 
That being said, the only reason this film wouldâ€™ve gotten such attention is by being a feature film. It got lots of buzz and got nominated for many awards for this reason. A short film would only get nominated for the best short film, and not the other ones like sound. So I donâ€™t blame that this film chose to go a feature length direction (and make an arguably worse â€œfilmâ€) rather than a short film direction to focus on just the experience.

Name: Midsommar
Review:
A lot to appreciate from a filmmaking perspective, but the journey was not worth it.Â 

I will commend Ari Aster for making films that are super risky with a limited budget. Every film of his has unsettling natures that explore themes of trauma, but still vary so widely from each other.Â 
Personally, I donâ€™t think heâ€™s my cup of tea because ultimately I donâ€™t enjoy the journey.Â 

As this film opened, I was very on board. The setup and filmmaking was perfect.Â 
The relationship our two leads were introduced with was so uniquely captured. This wasnâ€™t just two people in a loving relationship, or a relationship where one of them is clearly in the wrong. This was a strained relationship where we as the audience donâ€™t see major faults on either side, but at the same time understand why they have the negative conversations to each other. Setting up a complicated relationship like this is very difficult, but I was able to completely understand this complex relationship.Â 
The trauma that our lead character, Dani, was experiencing was completely understandable too. It can be difficult to convey trauma to audiences that havenâ€™t experienced the exact trauma that the character did, but I think this was done in a way where anyone can sympathize.Â 
Certain shots of the film that are normally simple shots were done in a fascinating manner (which continued through the rest of the runtime). Conversations happened across mirror shots, rather than both people actually being in camera. Camera pans were done in disorientingly well crafted directions. While I normally donâ€™t like the horror genre, the unsettling nature of these shots were so artistically crafted that I had to appreciate them and see how the film goes forward with this setup.Â 

Even once our characters arrive to the cult in Sweden, I was on board to see it out. The visuals of the commune had beautiful symmetrical shots.Â 
Normal horror films contain an ensemble of people that all love each other or all hate each other or one scapegoat. This ensemble was much more complex, with some people actually being friends while others feeling an obligation to not instigate anything. Yet, all of this relationship complexity is clearly communicated to the audience.Â 
The scene involving grass on Dani was very unsettling. I appreciate that this film doesnâ€™t do a bunch of gore for a similar reaction. There was a lot of thought put into how to craft this. It makes you feel that there is a lot to appreciate in the art, but it is still unsettling because it looks so wrong.Â 
Many unsettling setups and relationships were well crafted to make me really want to know what the film would do with these puzzle pieces.Â 

The second half of the film completely lost me. It leaned so much into shocking and nauseating horror without much purpose other than shock value. Without spoiling anything, the only horror elements I liked here were the visuals of dead bodies because they managed to be super creepy without the super gorey conventions. But other than that, I just donâ€™t understand the purpose of this film. The setup was meticulously crafted with unique complexities, and I felt they didnâ€™t get payoff in the end.Â 

I could see huge horror fans appreciating this more than me, but other than that I donâ€™t understand how this film is so popular from others.

Name: Remember the Titans
Review:
What a thrilling sports film!

This has been on my list for far too long, finally got around to it because I was tasked to watch an underdog story for my improv class this week. It has a classic underdog feel, but also has so much more to offer.Â 

The easy criticism is that this is a 2000 Disney film, so it follows a typical formula that simplifies the topic of 1970s racism and avoids the darker sides of history. I donâ€™t disagree per se, but I think what we see is fresh and important. The time period is after the Civil Rights Act, but still when racist sentiments clearly exist. So we see adults feeling nervous about white and black people in the same towns and schools. What I found most interesting is that we see the kids initially have these same sentiments, but then become the drivers of equality once they get to know each other. This was done very well, and filmed in a believable manner too.Â 
This film also does a good job of not making white people appear completely evil. Unfortunately I think a film made today would do this wrong. Here, we just see white people feel nervous at first but then open up to it later.Â 
Overall, while racism was a lot uglier than what we see in this film, we see enough of it to show kids about the terrible past we had, while also not overtaking feelings of pity through the film.Â 

This film also did a great job of educating themes through sports. The prime theme shown was that teammates need to work together to be a successful team. To do that, they have to put aside their racial differences to collaborate. Sports was a great way to educate this theme because sports is a venue where clear talent will win. One of my favorite scenes was when high school athletes learned this lesson naturally by wanting to win a practice run.Â 
Julius and Gerryâ€™s friendship was the most heartwarming aspect to me. They go from enemies to friends, and that arc felt completely natural.Â 

I appreciated that this didnâ€™t shoehorn romantic subplots. The focus of the film is correctly on the sports and the racism, and romance wouldâ€™ve detracted.Â 

I have two nitpicks.Â 
First, I didnâ€™t understand the choice of making Ronnie Bass a hippie. It seemed like an additional checkbox to add to this film unnecessarily. In addition, upon looking up the real character, he was nothing like this.Â 
Second, I wouldâ€™ve liked to see more struggle from Coach Booneâ€™s character. We see him say couple instances of struggle in his past while coaching the kids, but we donâ€™t see much more. He almost appears like a perfect character that never makes mistakes and never has negative emotions. This is great as a coach, but I wanted to see more of him behind the scenes on what motivated him.

Name: The Family Star
Review:
Giving this a thorough analysis is barely worth my time.Â 

Sometimes I tell myself that Iâ€™m too nice to certain movies, granting positive reviews to films that maybe donâ€™t deserve it. As I tell myself this, I then come across movies like this that are so bad that I appreciate mediocre movies as being â€œcompetent enoughâ€.Â 

This is a typical Telugu masala movie with a couple cute funny scenes, but all tarnished with stupid plot decisions.Â 

A â€œmysteryâ€ in the movie is set up as waiting to figure out the heroineâ€™s defense for a misunderstanding. This is set up near the beginning of the film but not addressed at any capacity until the tail end, and that too isnâ€™t fully explained. There are many other cases of setup and improper payoff like this.Â 

Ok done with actual reviewing, now Iâ€™m just going to stage actual scenes that happened in this film:
The hero wants to teach a lesson to his nieces and nephews on how to handle people that threaten your family. He does so by threatening to rape the women of the bad guyâ€™s family.Â 
In a serious scene, prostitution is morally equivalent to sex change.Â 
â€œI hope you marry a cripple or paraplegicâ€ is thrown as an insult.

Iâ€™m kinda proud of myself for having enough willpower to sit through until the end.

Name: Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom
Review: So much budget on screen, yet unfortunately so forgettable.Â  I thought the first Aquaman film was fine - I loved how crazy the underwater world was (e.g. octopus drummer), and I loved the surfer bro vibe of Jason Momoa in the lead. But, there wasnâ€™t much more that popped in the first film for me to give a strong positive recommendation.Â  This film seemed to have similar contents, but was much more conventional. Not enough world-building exploration of the underwater world. Humor that was bad versions of MCU quips, rather than leaning in more into Jason Momoa surfer bro vibes. Heroes and villains with many CGI army helpers that seemingly shoot up out of nowhere.Â  This film also suffers from being created after Avatar: The Way of WaterÂ was released. That had top-notch underwater fight scenes, while this one didnâ€™t feel as epic.Â  One brief shot made me really wish James Wan had full creative control of this film. There was a jump scare shot of a frozen skeleton within ice in an underwater exploration. It was a creative and effective jump scare. Also, an underwater zombie film sounds absolutely bonkers enough to be amazing.Â  I admittedly donâ€™t remember much lore of Aquaman from the previous DCEU installments, but it seems to not matter at all here. To be fair, seemed like the DCEU didnâ€™t care either, as they are just getting ready for a reboot.Â  Nothing in the film was really wrong per se, but it was way too conventional and we needed something more in the era of superhero fatigue to be interested. I really like the visuals of the underwater world, and I wouldâ€™ve been more positive if I couldâ€™ve at least experienced much more of that.

Name: Minari
Review:
A unique perspective of hard-working immigrants settling into the United States.Â 

I tend to not relate to films depicting immigrants in the US, because they seem to focus on weird things. A lot of them are depicted from the perspective of the kids who wish to deviate from the culture of their parents, with the filmâ€™s messaging being that the culture direction is incorrect. Or these films depict stereotypic quotes that just feel unrealistic.Â 
Thankfully, this film didnâ€™t go that direction.Â 

From the beginning, we are rooting for the best for this family. Jacob has big dreams and we root for his success. He risked it all to move to Arkansas to live in a weird home, start up a farm from scratch to make Korean produce typically not found in the US, and stayed as frugal as possible while still ensuring his family is supported. This is the type of immigrant story that needs to be depicted more in film.Â 
This film easily couldâ€™ve leaned into racism struggles of the immigrant family, but I think it was the right decision to focus on how they were assimilating into Arkansas life and the struggles associated with that.Â 

This film chose to go a direction of including other seemingly unrelated vignettes about each of the family members. I think the goal of this was to show how this is an everyday family that experiences struggles of holding the family together while trying to pursue the American Dream. But, I felt the runtime focused too much on these areas without providing a greater purpose. This made the journey a bit boring, even if I did relate to the characters well.

Name: Monkey Man
Review: Not to be confused with Hanu Man, this is another 2024 film about a protagonist inspired by the Hindu deity Hanuman to bring down the villain.Â  It hurts me to report that I didnâ€™t like this film.Â  The story behind the creation of this film is fascinating. It was an actual underdog tale of a passionate Dev Patel literally putting everything he had on the line to film this and Jordan Peele supporting a theatrical run for the film.Â  From the marketing, it seemed like the film had everything I would love in a film. An action thriller with brutal stunt work, the joy of supporting a small budget film in theaters, and a welcome exposure of Hinduism to international audiences.Â  Unfortunately, this was tough for me to sit through.Â  Iâ€™m really shocked that most audiences are positive with this film. My guess is that the India underworld setting is â€œfreshâ€ for western audiences. Personally, this isnâ€™t fresh for me given my long exposure to many Telugu masala films having such content.Â  The marketing made it seem like this film is nonstop action. In reality, there are only two (albeit long) action scenes. I have no problem with that - one of my favorite films last year was The Killer which only had action scene. But that film worked for me because even that one action scene was thrilling, and more importantly the rest of the film had a gripping nature to be invested. In this film, I needed more to root for how brutal the protagonist was willing to go for revenge. The use of heavy shaky cam was definitely good at making the whole setting feel chaotic, but it also made it hard to track what was going on in some moments. I understand that such stunt direction occurred to be creative through budget constraints, but to truly appreciate stunt work I have to like it regardless of knowing production background for a film. Given all this, I donâ€™t see a particular reason to view this in theaters. On that note, Iâ€™m not a die-hard of Jordan Peeleâ€™s film work, and Iâ€™m surprised that mass audiences treat him in the same regard as those like Steven Spielberg. I love Jordan Peele, but Iâ€™m not convinced he has a genius filmmaking brain.Â  Huge respect to Dev Patel for the dedication both in front of and behind the camera to get this project done. Iâ€™m all for more artists bringing their passion projects to screen. But, Iâ€™m more in awe of the underdog story for creating the film than the underdog story in the film.

Name: Mad Max
Review: This is a really confusing review to do now. Iâ€™m sure my opinion on this will completely change in the future, so I will just throw my thoughts down now.Â  My background before this point was only watching Mad Max: Fury Road. I really loved the practical effect set pieces in that movie. My plan is to watch the rest of the franchise before FuriosaÂ comes out.Â  From the second this film started, I was very confused about if this even is the same universe as Mad Max: Fury Road. I get that this film had barely any budget and no plans for a franchise, so itâ€™s like comparing apples and oranges. But as a comparison, I think itâ€™s pretty evident that the original Star WarsÂ film is in the same universe as every other property after it: costume design, space travel, lightsabers are all the same in all these films. Only difference is the budget.Â  Mad Max: Fury RoadÂ had many crazy people in wild costumes off-roading through deserts. On the other hand, pretty much everything in this film occurred in actual towns on actual paved roads. In addition, Max is introduced as a normal family man that is also a cop here. Overall not a crazy world.Â  I was admittedly kinda bored through the runtime, because many car chases and crashes were very simplistic and didnâ€™t have much obvious stakes or motive behind them. I later on looked up the production of this film and was pretty impressed retroactively: I had no idea that George Miller was a doctor and then decided to make a film with injuries that he saw as a doctor. And then illegally filmed shots on roads and was only allowed one take to do them due to budget restraints. Clearly there were risks taken to produce this film so I have to commend that.Â  It really isnâ€™t until the last few minutes when Max is truly â€œmadâ€. Which is funny to think about. This is the part where I really got on board, but most of the film had to go through to get to this point.Â  After I see the rest of the franchise, I may end up really appreciating this film as a solid origin story. Until then, Iâ€™ll keep this feeling for my review.Â  Sidebar- I really appreciate the â€œpuzzleâ€ at the end, which lowkey inspired Saw.

Name: Pete's Dragon
Review: Not a bad watch, but not super praiseworthy either.Â  I was looking forward to watch this film because it deviated from the Disney assembly line content. Unlike all the live-action adaptations that are remaking classic animations, this one was a remake of a property that was not as popular. I am all for remakes of â€œbadâ€ or â€œunpopularâ€ films to add a modern take and provide a fresh perspective.Â  Unfortunately, there isnâ€™t enough here for me to champion the film.Â  While this film went through all the typical Disney tropes, they were all properly executed and evoked the proper emotions at each beat. The child actor is undoubtedly charming. The opening scene was also great, getting similar emotions as the opening of Up. While it felt very similar to The Jungle Book (which is funny timing that both live-action adaptations were in 2016), itâ€™s a good formula so I was ready for it.Â  What didnâ€™t work for me here was the messy writing. Especially with the antagonist - He acted well, but his motive seemed to change conveniently at plot moments. Robert Redfordâ€™s character was initially not a major character, but then suddenly got very involved in the third act. Normally I donâ€™t have high expectations for sharp writing, but here it just took me out of the experience.Â  Itâ€™s a good one-time watch, but I donâ€™t expect this to be a classic for anyone.

Name: The Great Gatsby
Review: A whole lot of shine over nothing.Â  This book was one of my required readings in English class. Almost all books in English class were strongly uninteresting to me. And despite analyzing them to death through our assignments, I barely remember much about them. All I remembered about this content was that a car accident happened at some point, and it took place around the 1920s.Â  This film was only on my watchlist because of (a) Amitabh Bachchanâ€™s Hollywood appearance and (b) Baz Luhrmannâ€™s flashiness. I appreciate Baz Luhrmann as he has a style that elevated Romeo + Juliet and Moulin Rouge! but it didnâ€™t work for me for Elvis.Â  Overall, I felt Baz Luhrmannâ€™s style was a perfect fit for this story and definitely elevated my liking for the film. It was definitely deserving of awards for Production Design and Costume Design, everything was lovely to look at.Â  But, separating out the flash, I still found the story to be very boring and uninteresting. At the end of the day, the story is just a typical surface-level romance plot whose complications are easily avoidable if people just had a simple conversation with each other. The complications didnâ€™t feel like a fun journey at all.Â  Amitabh Bachchan ended up being in only one scene. Cool to see him in Hollywood, but no reason to see this film just for him.

Name: Her
Review:
This has been on my watchlist for a while, but definitely had to see it right after OpenAIâ€™s ChatGPT-4o presentation and the Google I/O Gemini presentation. Those showed the conversationalism of their AI assistants, which is the crux of this film.Â 

At the time of its release, the film was not really viewed as a creepy horror film. This was probably because the concept of people conversing so casually with an AI is too unrealistic to believe this is an actual world. How could an AI ingest all your emails, contact other people on your behalf, and even have a relationship?
Now in the post-ChatGPT area, this feels like a very real future. Itâ€™s creepy, but at the same time I canâ€™t help but commend how well the filmmakers realized this world 10 years ago (even before AirPods became a thing).

On that note, the world of this film has a lot to commend. This isnâ€™t a world with flying cars or anything. Itâ€™s a slightly future world, so it still has the some of the same things like metros. But at the same time, itâ€™s a fully realized world. We just happen to see Joaquin Phoenixâ€™s character as the protagonist, but we see all the background characters also have hands-free conversations (presumably with their own conversational AIs) in public. The slice of life nature of this film is very refreshing compared to traditional sci-fi films.Â 

While I normally donâ€™t like overly sexual inclusions in films, here I think it was necessary. At the time of this film, there was a lot of fear around people spending lots of their time on the internet. Now, the fear is definitely higher with conversational AI. I could definitely see a social world like this occur if AI is left unhinged.Â 

I felt it was very smart to cast Joaquin Phoenix in the lead role with such a personality. He is by no means the classic hot romantic lead type. He is aggressively normally and a bit awkward, but still has enough charm to grip the audience. It would make sense for a person of this type to find interest in a romantic relationship with an AI.Â 

Huge praise to Scarlett Johanssonâ€™s voice acting as the AI. It truly felt like an actual character in the film.Â 

This is a great film that I probably never want to see again because it will feel too real.

Name: Mad Max 2
Review: A solid action thriller! The previous films I saw in this franchise are Mad Max: Fury Road and Mad Max. Seeing the original made me greatly question if it truly was part of the franchise, but I figured it was just a drawn out origin story of Max. This film not only reassured me what the franchise is about, but it is absolutely epic. Sequels like this are so welcome because they are technically a possible continuation in the franchise, but make the effort to offer something new.Â  My favorite part about this film is the world-building. Most franchises throw lots of exposition to explain the rules of the world (e.g. prophecies, superpowers). This film might be the most effective world-building Iâ€™ve seen in that there is no exposition - everything is just shown and inferred. Itâ€™s a simple world - a post-apocalyptic world with no law and order. We just go straight to the action. This film knows the film itâ€™s trying to be and goes straight to it.Â  The lack of dialogue works for the better here, we donâ€™t need to grasp every detail of why people act the way they do. And as a result of not needing to focus so much on exposition, we got really efficient storytelling. This film is less than 100 minutes, and I felt like I saw so much action in that time.Â  The simplicity in the world-building is really smart for two main reasons. First, it elevates our view of the main character. Max isnâ€™t someone with superpowers or randomly appointed to become the chosen one. He is just someone with a sad past that is simply surviving the crazy world. We know he is still alive alone because he is talented enough with his skills to fend off enemies, and that is enough to root for him.Â  Second, I donâ€™t feel the need to watch films in order. All other franchises require you to do the homework to watch films in order to get the proper setup and payoff. Based on all the films Iâ€™ve seen in the franchise thus far, I donâ€™t have a need to search up wikis of every character and/or object. All the films seem to just be adventures that happen in a simply explained post-apocalyptic world. I can just relax and enjoy all these films.Â  Itâ€™s super interesting to compare this film to Mad Max: Fury Road. In almost every way itâ€™s the same film with crazy contraptions on cars chasing each other, just with a generational difference of movie effects. I feel that both can still exist in the same universe because this film takes a dirtier and less cinematic route. Ultimately I like both of these takes equally.Â  I initially expected Mad Max: Fury RoadÂ to be ten times wilder than others in the franchise. This film was just as wild, with a solo helicopter contraption and flamethrower and everything.Â  In a time of film when everything has an overuse of CGI, this type of world is very refreshing. Itâ€™s all scrappy lifestyles, with monster trucks as gates to a civilization instead of an automatic door.Â  The twist at the end was something I totally didnâ€™t expect, which is commendable considering how old this film is.Â  The only other films I can think of that try to copy the formula of this film is the Fast & Furious franchise. I retroactively probably donâ€™t appreciate the Fast & Furious franchise as much anymore because this franchise nails raw actiony chaos way better.Â  This film has been hailed as one of the best action films of all time. Going into a film with such expectations is dangerous, but I genuinely canâ€™t find any faults with this. Time will tell if I still feel this positive about this film, but for now I agree with all the hype.

Name: Madame Web
Review:
Itâ€™s obviously very easy to hate on this movie because everyone else is. I was hoping to have some way to defend this film, but sadly there isnâ€™t anything defendable.Â 

What made the experience extra frustrating for me is that this had the pieces to stand out amongst the superhero fatigue. Madame Webâ€™s superpower of inconsistently seeing glimpses of the future is fascinating. That alone is enough to drive a whole film. A whole act to figure out how to master the superpower, and eventually using wits to defeat a supervillain. 
Dakota Johnson was even perfectly cast as Madame Web. The three teenage girls were also perfectly cast.Â 
But, the film chose to go in the most conventional directions ever.Â 

I genuinely never cared about any character in this film. It was hard to, with haphazard editing and plot choices. The last thing any sane person would do after nearly getting killed is to bring attention to themselves by dancing on a table in a diner. Countless moments like this were just unforgivable.Â 

It truly seemed like this film was made out of obligation. I donâ€™t understand how such projects get greenlit to theaters. It shouldâ€™ve been pretty obvious during production that no one cared here. If everyday audiences laugh at the acting and dialogue in the film, shouldnâ€™t studio executives catch that and prevent its release?

Name: The Iron Claw
Review:
A continuously tragic biopic of the wrestling careers of the von Erich family.Â 

I am totally not into wrestling or boxing (or any fighting sports) but somehow I accept them in film. I also knew absolutely nothing about the true story, so all the story beats were very gut-wrenching to me.Â 

Huge respect to Zac Efron - he has done very well at transforming from Disney Channel beginnings to a respectable actor. He was almost unrecognizable here with his physique. He clearly put in a lot of physical and mental work into this film, and Iâ€™d argue very deserving of awards recognition. He not only had the physique of a wrestler but the emotional beats, and it is difficult to do both. Without spoiling anything, the end of the film is totally gut-wrenching.Â 

The father figure was a unique personality I havenâ€™t seen before. You can clearly see his actions can lean to areas of abuse and overworking, but at the same time you get why his sons respect him.Â 

One aspect that felt odd to me is how easy it seemed for every brother to have a chance at the world championship. I personally view sports as the one place where you genuinely have to earn your position because the talent is clearly measurable. So the thought of another brother casually deciding to join the sport felt odd.Â 

I donâ€™t really view this overall as a must-see, there are other sports dramas that offer more.Â 

This film also felt slightly over in its runtime.

Name: In the Heights
Review: A musical time-pass.Â  I always have a soft spot for musicals, so Iâ€™ve been looking forward to watch this film. Iâ€™m admittedly not a huge Hamilton fan (and to be honest, I donâ€™t know how itâ€™s so popular), but Lin-Manuel Mirandaâ€™s musical writing is very commendable and I was intrigued by the vibrancy from the trailers. I went blind going into this, as I knew nothing about the Broadway show.Â  I can report that this film lived up well to what the trailers marketed. The fast-paced musical numbers had infectious energy (and thank goodness for subtitles allowing me to follow along with the lyrics). All the actors ooze in charisma through their characters. While plays arenâ€™t my artistic cup of tea, I love how this film kept some stage presence choreography.Â  Musicals seem to accomplish the impossible of making the runtime fly by, even though plot development is essentially stopped when a musical number occurs. I think this is possible when the energy of the musical is strong, and it totally is here.Â  My favorite musical numbers were the ones that involved many people - I just wanted to join the party they were having.Â  I think the only other John M. Chu film Iâ€™ve seen is Crazy Rich Asians. The vibrancy of cultures and set pieces in this film felt flashingly similar to Crazy Rich Asians. Overall, great choice to have John M. Chu direct.Â  The utilization of a primarily Dominican ethnic presence was very unique. I normally avoid commending diversity for the sake of diversity, but it was very enjoyable to dip into the lens of a new culture for me.Â  There were multiple plot choices that felt out of place. All were moments that seemingly had hints of relatability to modern political themes. After watching the film, I researched about the original musical, and in fact all these plot choices were changes from the original musical. Time will tell if the choice of political leanings will bode well for the legacy of this film, but overall I think the choices made plot developments worse and I wish the original film choices were kept.

Name: Crew
Review:
Great premise, ok execution.Â 

Three A-list actresses as scheming air hostesses is a super fun premise. Itâ€™s clear that the actresses loved being a part of this project. I was overall on board with all the plot choices made here.Â 

A couple things didnâ€™t work for me perfectly.Â 
Mainly, there is a lot of adult humor that didnâ€™t land well. The premise itself is hilarious, and I wish the comedic moments focused on the plot instead of insignificant sidebars. Improving this piece of it wouldâ€™ve easily made this a fun adventure for the whole family.Â 

The pacing isnâ€™t fast-paced. The premise was enough for me to stick around until the end of the film. But, a faster pace wouldâ€™ve made this feel more thrilling.Â 

A nitpick is that there is a fair amount of unrealism to buy into. This isnâ€™t a major con for me, since the concept of air hostesses doing schemes is unrealistic in itself. But, I had enough of these thoughts to point it out.

This has been on my list for too long to watch on at least of television screen, so I quickly jumped to watch it on Netflix once it arrived there. I was afraid of having too high expectations, but I ended up still thoroughly enjoying it.Â 

Many criticisms seem to highlight the fact that this film was just surface level and donâ€™t explore as much war themes as other war films. I very much disagree with this as a criticism, because I saw this more as a thriller than a war film. I think too much exploration of deep war themes would have taken away the great gift that this film had.Â 
In my opinion, a war setting was perfect for this screenplay. Just by being set in a war zone in the middle of World War I, we know that walking a short distance alone is an adventure with constant danger. We didnâ€™t need to waste exposition time to grasp this fact.Â 

Many (including myself) have been disappointed with films based on video games because the film ends up feeling like an assembly line production instead of capturing the same adrenaline rush feelings of the source material. The choice of making it all see like one shot wasnâ€™t just a gimmick but a thrill in the way that video games feel like. We feel like weâ€™re held into a fixed perspective of these characters on a journey, and experience their sufferings that never get a break. When long one-shots happen, I typically have the need to focus on if it was a well edited one-shot, instead of just enjoying the scenes of the film. Here, I barely had the crisp eyesight on the editing techniques because I was busy appreciating the journey of the film.Â 

I think what really sold this film for me was our lead characters (and their actors seriously deserved awards consideration). They were not superheroes with powers, but regular people with a â€œsimpleâ€ goal. In many ways, Iâ€™m sure all audience members see a little of themselves suffering to try reaching their goal.
It was particularly wise to have one of the lead characters be someone that was kinda forced into the situation with no personal stakes. One would think that personal stakes are important, but here it added a layer of feeling that he really didnâ€™t deserve to suffer the amount he is.Â 

This adventure will be thrilling for anyone, and I highly recommend a watch at your earliest convenience!

Name: Godzilla Minus One
Review:
Wow.Â 

I obviously heard all the hype around this film, but I was still very skeptical on how a Godzilla film could really be that amazing. A random monster wreaking havoc could only be so entertaining, right? 
The only Godzilla film Iâ€™ve seen before was the 2014 Hollywood film, which I enjoyed but wouldnâ€™t rave about. I never explored any of the lore from the international productions (and wow there are so many).Â 

After finally watching the film, I understand the hype.Â 

I heard that the characters were the best part of the film, but I really wasnâ€™t prepared for just how well the characters were developed.Â 
The protagonistâ€™s characteristics were the perfect choice for this film. Heâ€™s not a macho hero. In fact, heâ€™s the opposite. He starts off as a coward. I really only remember protagonists that maybe start out evil and then go through a redemption arc. Starting as a coward was a wise choice because it made him have opportunity for redemption, yet still deserve the audience to root for him. 
The family dynamic was surprisingly relatable too. Most Hollywood productions will have a love story grow amidst a disaster, which is so unrealistic and feels obligatory. Here, the family isnâ€™t even a biological family, but fate brought them together to have familial relationships. The relationships were strong because you could tell that each member needed each other for strength. Their humanistic natures told them it was their duty to care for each other. The continuation of this familial nature through the rest of the film was so strong and touching. 
I almost view this film as a human nature film that happens to have Godzilla in it, rather than a Godzilla disaster movie. The classic statement from critics is that the characters are the most important part of the story. Flesh out the characters, rather than the spectacle. This film follows that rule with flying colors.Â 
Bringing Godzilla as the villain into this story was smart. A token superhero movie would have had a supervillain eventually kidnap the wife and kids of the hero, so that the hero gets angry and lead to a giant third act battle. Here, Godzilla was more a venue to provide a character arc for the protagonist. In a way, that made Godzilla even scarier and made us want to root for the protagonist more.Â 

It was also very smart to set this film right after World War II. Japan was obviously still weak and broken at this point, still recovering from the war. So battling a giant nuclear monster right after human enemies is super demotivating. However, the motivation for everyone came in a patriotic sense for protecting the land for their loved ones, rather than for their government. It was really refreshing to hear patriotic vibes like this, rather than surface-level statements.Â 

The one flaw for me was with the third act resolutions. I understand why the choices can make symbolic sense, but to me they sacrificed the realism that was earned from the first two acts.Â 

Very commendable that this film was made on such a low budget - Hollywood should take notes. This also proves that A-list star power isnâ€™t required.Â 

I initially thought that the â€œMinus Colorâ€ version of the film was just a blatant cash grab. It probably is, but I fully understand how a black-and-white version of this film would be even more epic.Â 

Can someone tell me what â€œMinus Oneâ€ means from the title? I genuinely donâ€™t understand that.

Name: Beverly Hills Cop
Review:
A fun action comedy!

Despite this film being many years ago, it still feels pretty fresh. I understand why Eddie Murphy was a big star back in the day, if he had performances like this one. He elevated an otherwise conventional plot into something more. My favorite moments were whenever Eddie Murphy acted brash but smart.

The film doesn't really execute any amazingly enough to recommend or be hyped about its subsequent films, but it is a solid watch for anyone wanting an action comedy.

The "Axel F" song is so overused here, but I bopped to it every time it came up so I didn't mind it at all.

I got real surprised that Jonathan Banks was in this film, didn't even recognize him. It was only when I subsequently Google'd when I realized who he was. Wow, looks so different from his Breaking Bad/Better Call Saul moments!

This film was apparently one of the highest grossing films of its year. I wish we could go back to a time like this, where mid-budget surprise hits could be possible. Now, the highest grossing films are ones that are big budget sequels or big budget IP projects. I would love to experience a mid-budget surprise in the theater with many strangers.

Name: Uunchai
Review:
What a heartwarming, unique tale!

This has been on my list for a while. I adore anything Amitabh Bachchan does - unlike most Indian actors, he manages to both have a huge range in projects and actually acts his age. Also huge respect to Boman Irani and Anupam Kher, they also have had solid careers.
But most importantly, the concept of this film is beautiful. The idea of three old men hiking Mount Everest is beautiful. 

The film lived up to its concept by providing many heartwarming moments. Any time I saw the three of them pushing themselves to continue on the hike, I got emotional. Any of us will see our own grandparents in these three men and get inspired.
I wish more films like this can become profitable. Unfortunately, the masses want to see more flash with young people in their films, even if they lack personality.

This film is also definitely very long. I usually scorn when a film goes past 2.5 hours. But here, the warmth of witnessing our leads overcoming barriers continued to feel fresh for me so I didn't mind the runtime.
Although, the main criticism for me was a lot of unnecessary subplots. I understand fleshing out the personalities of the three men, as they had great chemistry together. But, the film chose to include a lot more information about all of them that ultimately didn't feel that relevant. I was gripped enough with the three of them banding together.

The personalities amongst the 3 of them were very fun and they had great chemistry. But, there were moments when the humor got too silly to be juxtaposed with the strenuous hikes. Less humor during these moments could've made the journey a lot more believable.

The film chose to open the film with a scene of them hiking, and then flashing back to their backstories of why they got there. A nitpick, but I felt this was an odd choice. We see their pushbacks for why they cannot do this trip, but knowing that they eventually overcome these pushbacks almost made me not as invested about them and I just wanted to cut back to Mount Everest.

Name: Fighting with My Family
Review:
A solid sports film, elevated by a great blend of humor from the main family.Â 

Iâ€™ve seen many sports films recently (e.g. every film in the Rocky/Creed franchise) and I keep thinking Iâ€™ll get sick of the genre. Somehow I still havenâ€™t - this might be my new guilty pleasure genre.Â 

The best part of this film is how itâ€™s able to blend its silly humor into a sports film. Usually, this is a turn-off (e.g. the worst offenses of the MCU). Here, it works because the main family is so chaotically weird as caricatures that I wanted to keep seeing more of them (in particular, every interaction with the girlfriendâ€™s parents - Stephen Merchant and Julia Davis - were too funny). At the same time, we could easily relate to all the family beats. For this reason, I think this is a sports film that is able to be accessible to all audiences. It has all the sports beats without the overly masculine aspects.Â 

My god, Florence Pugh. She has so much range across all her filmography. I will genuinely put her amongst the greats like Leonardo DiCaprio. I believed all of her actions as a wannabe wrestler and all the emotional struggles that come with it. I even believed her as someone that is a natural goth, even though she obviously is not.Â 

Even after watching this film, I still donâ€™t understand the concept of staged wrestling. It made me question the point of some training montages and why certain people got cut.Â 

Overall, a fun watch for all audiences!

Name: Tower Heist
Review: A surprisingly fun comedy heist adventure! I didnâ€™t really know what to expect going into this film, but itâ€™s been on my watchlist for a while. Any time I kept trying to watch it, it would get off the streaming service. This time I decided to just watch it before it comes off Netflix again.Â  I did not realize how stacked this cast was (Matthew Broderick, Casey Affleck, Tea Leoni, etc.). And every cast member is having a blast on screen. Iâ€™m kinda surprised I havenâ€™t heard of this film much as a cult following.Â  Ben Stiller was my favorite part of the film. From the beginning, I felt his passion for his role with the building manager role. It made his motive for the heist believable rather than obligatory. It even made me believe the setup (even through ludicrous details). Seeing this film right after Beverly Hills Cop, I felt like I was just watching Eddie Murphyâ€™s typical fun character again. I didnâ€™t realize that this was a welcome addition amongst reviews because Eddie Murphy had a break from these types of characters. I retroactively can understand why Eddie Murphyâ€™s character could excite people.Â  As the runtime continued, some details became inconsistent and started causing faults in my mind. For example, while the existence of the characters of Matthew Broderick and Tea Leoni were very fun, they didnâ€™t really make much sense for the plot. Also, building hanging in the third act got way too ludicrous.Â  I still strongly prefer heist films like Oceanâ€™s Eleven and The Italian Job, but this is a good watch if you want more of a silly vibe with your heists.

Name: Run
Review: This has been on my list for way too long. I love Aneesh Changanty after Searching, and I really needed to see his next film. Finally made time for it now.Â  I really liked the setup in this film. A teenager with a plethora of medical issues that starts to question her motherâ€™s caretaking. I was veryÂ glad with certain details being properly executed, all rooted from the casting of Kiera Allen. Not only is she a great actress, but she actually cannot walk. This made all crawling and wheelchair scenes look believable because she has done that her whole life.Â  The later half ended up going through the typical psychological thriller beats. This alone wouldnâ€™t be a criticism for me, but there was also a weird relaxation of perfecting all the details. Convenient newspaper article placements and stupid behaviors from side characters took effect near the end. They didnâ€™t make me hate the film, but it was definitely a step down from the premise.Â  I will still fully support Aneesh Chagantyâ€™s next adventures, but likely wonâ€™t watch this one again.

Name: Schindler's List
Review: Finally, Iâ€™ve experienced this film. Spielberg is my favorite director, yet I havenâ€™t seen this until now. Iâ€™ve heard all the praise about this film being one of his best. How this man made this and Jurassic ParkÂ in the same year. How you havenâ€™t really understood the harrowing nature of the Holocaust until this film.Â  I finally got here. And despite all the impossible praises of the film, I agree with all the praise.Â  The serious side of Spielberg is admittedly still new to me. I closely associate him with iconic blockbusters. Saving Private Ryan is the only recent serious film of his that Iâ€™ve seen that has opened my eyes on what he is able to accomplish. I didnâ€™t think it was possible for him to go beyond that. Turns out, he did with this film.Â  Thank you, Steven Spielberg, for educating me about this point of history. Itâ€™s obviously one thing to hear about the unforgivable nature of Hitler and Anne Frankâ€™s diary explaining what it was like to be in hiding. But visually seeing the behavior of Nazi officers on the Jews was disgusting.Â  I really loved the choice of making this a black and white film. It somehow made everything much more horrific. It did not make the film less interesting, as I expected going into it.Â  I really liked the portrayal of Oskar Schindler here. Yes, everyone views him as a hero. But it was important to show his beginnings. At the beginning, he was purely a businessman that was profiting from Jewish labor. You could tell that he knew horrific things were happening to Jewish people, but at the time didnâ€™t do anything about it until he could see a profit from it. This was an important display of an everyday personâ€™s complicit nature through the genocide.Â  This beginning portrayal also made his emotional breakdown near the end much more impactful, knowing that he genuinely couldâ€™ve done more. Wow, I didnâ€™t know there was this side of Liam Neeson. He is now in the same throwaway action film every few months, but now I see what is seriously capable of. As much as I love Tom Hanks, Liam Neeson seriously deserved the Oscar for Best Actor. What a snub.Â  Also a snub was Ralph Fiennes for Best Supporting Actor. Now I understand why he got cast as Lord Voldemort eventually. This villainous scum made my blood boil for every second he was on screen. The amount of throwaway death caused by this man was jarring.Â  I watched The Zone of InterestÂ earlier this year. Yes, that is a jarring look at the Holocaust. But I couldnâ€™t help but feel like something was missing from that film. On the other hand, everything was present here. A captivating story capturing all the gross offenses through the Holocaust. The long runtime didnâ€™t feel long at all - it felt necessary to capture everything.Â  This is a must watch for everyone to never forget the Holocaust.

Name: The After
Review:
I knew nothing about this short (other than it got an Oscar nomination) and I am glad I did that.Â 

Iâ€™m pretty surprised how many people didnâ€™t like this. I felt all the emotional beats that the short wanted me to. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve felt grief as closely to a main character as this one.Â 
Given the super short runtime, I will probably want to rewatch this with someone else to discuss the depiction of grief here. I thought it was captured very well, and Iâ€™m curious what other people would feel.Â 

My only flaw is that Iâ€™m not sure what the goal is (other than depicting grief). This is a criticism I have of many shorts - I wish it was longer to flesh some of this out. Iâ€™m sure there are financial barriers preventing longer runtimes from creators. But, I canâ€™t help but feel like something more needed to be communicated from here and it just didnâ€™t.

Name: Inside Out 2
Review: I had very mixed feelings going into this one. Inside Out is one of my favorite films ever. It taught me that feeling emotions other than joy is normal and valuable to grow. I still look back to those themes today whenever I feel down. Also, the end of that film tied up with a great bow of memories with mixed emotions.Â  I was afraid that a sequel could undo some of the themes and growth of Inside Out. Also, the idea of more emotions seemed to undo the idea of mixed emotions at the end of the first film.Â  I admittedly still prefer no sequels in this franchise, but if we need sequels then this is definitely a welcome one.Â  From the very beginning hockey game showing how all the emotions work together to get Riley through this game, I already got emotional somehow. Films like this are why I love film. I donâ€™t relate to Oscar bait because they donâ€™t seem like they are truly trying to bring happiness and entertainment to audiences. Films like this one are so high energy and well thought out to bring all the right stimulus out of audiences.Â  I was very happy with this filmâ€™s portrayal of the teenage years. Every coming-of-age film has an obligatory need to include a romance subplot. So I was glad that this film went a smarter direction. It focused on a story involving old friends vs. new friends, and following your passions vs. controlling stresses. These are aspects that all adults have experienced, and they were communicated well to kids who will soon experience it themselves. This all then culminated into tear jerking moments in the third act that were very well earned and would be a good message to children.Â  My main flaw is that I didnâ€™t like that Riley was portrayed as a straight A student through it all. The first film worked well because Riley was relatable with all her struggles through childhood. She had relatable teenage struggles here too (as mentioned earlier), but further showing imperfections couldâ€™ve been a more relatable character to us.Â  Another nitpick was the inclusion of many more emotions. It was a risk to double the number of emotions, and that too have them be named with niche words. Five emotions in the first film made it easy to track why each emotion reacts the way they do in certain situations.
